Education & Training

Our mission is to improve the care of older patients locally and nationally through outstanding teaching and design of innovative curricula. We train physicians and other health professionals from first year students to seasoned clinicians in settings ranging from classroom to clinic and hospital to home.

Patient Care

We are specialists who provide person-centered medical care that reaches older persons where ever they need it--in hospitals, clinics or in their homes. Dignity, independence and choice are the focus of every healthcare decision.

Learn More »

 

Research

Our research is grounded in a deep respect for older persons, and a commitment to improving their health, well-being, and quality of life. Our commitment extends to all older persons across the spectrum of the aging experience.

Learn More »

Innovations

We are 116 faculty, fellows, and staff whose work is grounded in deep commitment to and respect for older persons. We are specialists in aging and palliative medicine. Our expertise is in optimizing the health of older individuals and those with serious illness. We work in the community and on virtually every UCSF campus Parnassus, San Francisco Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital, Laurel Heights, Mission Bay, and UCSF Center for Geriatric Care.

Our Work

We are specialty-trained doctors who provide the care patients want, when they want it, and where they want it. We care for patients in their homes and in hospitals, clinics, and long-term care settings. As teachers, we focus on producing the best clinicians, scientists, teachers and the next generation of leaders in geriatric medicine and palliative medicine. As scientists, we seek to understand the causes and outcomes of illness as we age, and to improve the health and well-being of older persons and those with serious illness.

Our Vision

The vision of the UCSF Division of Geriatrics is to transform health care to optimize aging and improve well-beingno matter an individual's health or situation. Our goal is for everyone to receive person-centered medical care care that helps them safely navigate the health care system, maintain dignity and independence, and experience improved quality of life and well-being.

Our Values

Respect, Service, Innovation, Quality, Integrity, Collaboration, Division Success, Achievement

The vision of the UCSF Division of Geriatrics is to transform health care to optimize aging and improve well-beingno matter an individual's health or situation.

Advance Care Planning for Future Medical Decisions

11/15/2016: It is important that our wishes about medical care, should we become incapable of making our own decisions, be known. Find out what you need to know about life-planning decisions including the living will/advance directive and durable power of attorney for health care. This course was made possible by the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF which is supported by the UCSF Geriatrics Workforce Enhancement Program: Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Grant Number U1QHP28727. Series: "UCSF Osher Center for Integrative Medicine presents Mini Medical School for the Public".

What is My Prognosis? Using information on Life Expectancy to Make Important Decisions

11/8/2016: Alex Smith, MD, MPH is a clinician-researcher at the University of California San Francisco who is at the forefront of efforts to integrate geriatrics and palliative care. This course was made possible by the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF which is supported by the UCSF Geriatrics Workforce Enhancement Program: Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Grant Number U1QHP28727. Series: "UCSF Osher Center for Integrative Medicine presents Mini Medical School for the Public".

Thinking and Doing: Cognitive Aging and Function

11/1/2016: There are many normal physiological changes that come with aging. Anne Fabiny, MD helps distinguish those from the pathological changes of disease or illness. Then, Craig Wingate of the Alzheimer's Association, provides clues to differentiate typical aging with Alzheimer's. When we can make that distinction we can focus on being resilient, sustaining a sense of purpose and vitality, even while coping with stressful experiences. This course was made possible by the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF which is supported by the UCSF Geriatrics Workforce Enhancement Program: Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Grant Number U1QHP28727.

Medication Optimization

10/25/2016: Powerful medicines save lives but also carry risks. Find out how to avoid excessive or unnecessary use of medications while achieving the desired benefits. John Newman, MD, PhD and Pharmacist Kirby Lee look at the principles of medication in older adults and caution that too much of anything, including medicine, can cause harm. This course was made possible by the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF which is supported by the UCSF Geriatrics Workforce Enhancement Program: Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Grant Number U1QHP28727.

Health Benefits of Staying Social: Connecting with Your Community

10/18/2016: The complexities of aging and health can result in loneliness and social isolation. Carla Perissinotto, MD, MHS , UCSF Division of Geriatrics, looks at the health effects of being lonely, who is at risk and what you can do. Then take a look at programs that provide services older adults and their caregivers. This course was made possible by the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF which is supported by the UCSF Geriatrics Workforce Enhancement Program: Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Grant Number U1QHP28727.

Staying Active At Every Ability Level: Mobility and Activity

10/11/2016: Mobility is important for health. Learn about mobility, activity, function and falls and how these relate to health. Then explore ways to assess and improve your mobility with an activity plan. This course was made possible by the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF which is supported by the UCSF Geriatrics Workforce Enhancement Program: Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Grant Number U1QHP28727. Series: "UCSF Osher Center for Integrative Medicine presents Mini Medical School for the Public".

Too Many Tests and Treatments: Why More is Not Always Better For Seniors

2/16/2016: Ken Covinsky, MD, MPH explains that there can be too many tests and treatments, especially for seniors. Series: "UCSF Osher Center for Integrative Medicine presents Mini Medical School for the Public".

Easing the Pain: Innovative and Effective Approaches to Managing Pain

6/16/2015: Pain is common in the setting of serious illness. Christine Ritchie, MD, MSPH, FACP, FAAHPM, UCSF distinguished professor, explains that it is a complex experience influenced by biology, environment and one's emotions and cognitions. While there are many effective medicines for pain, they also have significant side effects. A holistic approach includes pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic approaches to pain with input and support from an interdisciplinary team. Series: "UCSF Osher Center for Integrative Medicine presents Mini Medical School for the Public".

Giving Your Loved Ones the Gift of Knowing What You Want: Advance Care Planning

5/26/2015: Rebecca Sudore, MD, Associate Professor of Medicine at UCSF, explains that the goal of advanced care planning is to make sure that the medical care a person gets is the medical care that is in line with her or his life goals and values and to prepare people and their loved ones to make informed choices based on what is most important. Series: "UCSF Osher Center for Integrative Medicine presents Mini Medical School for the Public".

One UCSF: Carla Perissinotto, MD, MHS

3/2015: Carla Perissinotto, MD, MHS, is a geriatrician who helps people live longer, more comfortable, more fulfilling lives. She works with elderly patients through UCSF Care at Home, which provides medical care to home-bound older adults. She visits patients in their home so she can assess their environment and determine the best care plan to keep them safe and living independently. Dr. Perissinotto discusses her passion for her work in geriatrics and how it contributes to the UCSF mission of advancing health worldwide.

Mission In A Minute

4/1/2014: Dr. Dandan Liu is an associate professor of medicine with the UCSF Division of Geriatrics. Her research interests have included dementia and the stigma associated with it among the Asian-American community and most recently medication challenges faced by elderly patients after hospital discharge. She is now a full-time clinician dedicated to improving the quality of care for frail elderly with the hopes of inspiring the next generation of geriatric savvy future clinicians.

Falls in Older Adults

2/20/2014: Falls are a threat to the health and independence of older adults potentially limiting their self-sufficiency. Louise Aronson, MD, MFA, Associate Professor of Geriatrics, University of California San Francisco, explores how to try to prevent falls in older adults, and promote safety, health and independence.

Mission In A Minute

1/27/2014: Dr. Carla Perissinotto was selected to make a "Mission in a Minute" video about her mission to improve the lives of vulnerable older adults. The Mission in a Minute video series shines a spotlight on the work of extraordinary people at UC San Francisco. These brief videos allow UCSF faculty to quickly summarize their work, its importance and how it relates to the overall mission at UCSF. The series aims to inspire and inform the world about the many ways scientists, scholars, clinicians, and trainees carry out their work as part of the University's mission to advance health worldwide.

Geriatric News Items for the week of December 20, 2010
Division Faculty author an article in the Journal of Hospital Medicine
Lindsay Mazotti and Elizabeth Murphy, two former Reynolds Scholars, along with Mike Harper, Bree Johnston, Adam Moylan and Karen Hauer have authored an article in the Journal of Hospital Medicine. This article summarizes how faculty development programs focused on geriatric teaching can be challenging to complete because of cost and time for constraints. It also describes a successful model designed to equip hospitalists with knowledge and skills to teach geriatric topics to residents in a time-constrained, resource-limited environment. Read Article
 
Jessamyn Connell-Price is featured in the New York Times for "Empathy 101" Program

The UCSF-UC Berkeley Joint Medical Program has undertaken a novel program of intergenerational learning:  "Empathy 101" is led by Geriatrician Guy Micco, MD and sponsored in part by UCSFs Northern California Geriatrics Education Center. The New York Times article on Emphathy 101 features our friend Jessamyn Conell-Price, former Research Assistant in the Division of Geriatrics and current medical student.

Read the blog
 
Drug could stimulate aging imune system
UCSF researchers have identified an existing medication that restores key elements of the immune system that, when out of balance, lead to a steady decline in immunity and health as people age. The identification of a drug to reverse the immunological decline in aging, known as immunosenescence, is the culmination of years of research by Edward J. Goetzl, MD, at UCSF and the National Institute on Aging. Read UCSF News Release
Geriatric News Items for the week of December 13, 2010
Joanne Dang receives the Great People Award
Joanne Dang, Research Services Analyst, has received the Great People Award. The Great People Award recognizes employees whose daily contributions highlight the great diversity of work within the School of Medicine and honors employees whose commitment and values make their jobs a positive experience and the School of Medicine a great place to work. 
 
Michi Yukawa is first author for an article in the Journal of Nutrition

Michi Yukawa, MD, MPH, Associate Professor and Medical Director for the San Francisco VAMC Community Living Center is first author for an article in The Journal of Nutrition, Health titled, Circulating TNF alpha receptor levels identify older adults who fail to regain weight after acute weight loss

 
 
Drs. Mike Steinman and Eric Widera are recognized by the editors of the JGIM
Drs. Mike Steinman and Eric Widera were recognized by the editors of the Journal of General Internal Medicine for being superior reviewers.  The editors noted the critical role reviewers play in publishing good science.  Mike and Eric were recognized among a select number of exceptional reviewers because the exceptional quality of their reviews had an important role in improving the quality of research published in the Journal.
Geriatric News Items for the week of December 6, 2010
The Division of Geriatrics announces the first annual Geriatrics Scholarship Award Summit

The UCSF Division of Geriatrics is excited to announce the first annual Geriatrics Scholarship Award Summit open to ACGME interns and residents in Internal Medicine or Family Medicine. The goal of the Award is to stimulate interest in a career in academic geriatrics by recognizing residents scholarly or research achievements in aging or geriatrics.  Each award carries with it a cash prize of $500 plus a stipend to cover travel and lodging in San Francisco to present at a special award summit.

Award Details and Application

 
Eric Widera is interviewd by the New York Times
Eric Widera was recently interviewed by the New York Times' Paula Span regarding the possibilities of changing the term "Do Not Resuscitate (DNR)" to "Allow Natural Death (AND)". See either the New Old Age post or further thoughts on GeriPal.
Geriatric News Items for the week of November 29, 2010
Theresa Allison, MD has published an article in the Journal of Aging
Theresa Allison, MD has published an article in the Journal of Aging, Humanities and the Arts which will be available this month. The article titled, "The nursing home as village: Lessons from ethnomusicology" details the role of music in creating a more humane model of nursing home care.
 
Bree Johnston and Mike Harper receive funding for ACE Unit at SF VA Medical Center
Bree Johnston and Mike Harper have received 2 years of funding from the VA Central Office to start a ten bed interdisciplinary Acute Care of Elders (ACE) Unit at the San Francisco VA Medical Center.

The Unit's purpose is to improve hospital care for older patients, reduce common inpatient complications such as falls and delirium, and enhance the transition from hospital back to home. Construction on the Unit is due to begin this month, and will include creation of a group activity room, and renovation of the hospital rooms to be more "elder friendly". The interdisciplinary ACE team includes Linda Chetaitis (Clinical Nurse Specialist), Michael Nowicki (Pharmacist), Lok Chan (Occupational Therapist), Victoria Wright (Physical Therapist), and Franklin Niemi (Social Worker). The Unit will also be used for teaching health professionals about best practices of caring for elders in the inpatient setting.
 
Geriatric Prognosis website is launched
Lindsey Yourman a 4th year medical student at UCSF and Pre-Doc Research Fellow for the Division of Geriatrics has been working on the Systematic Review of Indices to Predict Life Expectancy. Lindsey, Sei Lee, Eric Widera, Alex Smith, Mara Schonberg and Cyrus Ahalt have all been working on this project and are excited that a draft of the www.eprognosis.org (Geriatric Prognosis Calculators) website is up and running. Their goal is to create a website that will be a repository of published geriatric prognostic indexes where clinicians can go to obtain evidence-based information on patients prognosis.
 
Louise Walter gives keynote address

Louise Walter, MD gave the keynote address "Breast Cancer Screening Guidelines and Controversies" at the 2010 California Regional Meeting of the Society of General Internal Medicine and the American College of Physicians on November 20, 2010.
 
Lindsey Yourman and Bree Johnston prepare to present a summary of the Geriatric Curriculum

Lindsey Yourman a 4th year medical student at UCSF, Pre-Doc Research Fellow and Bree Johnston, MD Professor of Medicine for the Division of Geriatrics are planning to present a summary of the Geriatric Curriculum for medical students (special thanks to Lisa Leiva for her computer skills) at WIP on December 15th!
 
The Division of Geriatrics leads UCSFs application to NIH for an Older Americans Independence Center
The Division of Geriatrics led UCSFs application to NIH for an Older Americans Independence Center.  The Center would find a welcoming home at UCSF, although only 1 in 10 new applications is generally funded.  Titled The Predictors, Consequences, and Amelioration of Late-life Disability: A Focus on Vulnerable Populations, the UCSF application proposed 5 Research Career Development Scholars (Michelle Odden, Wendy Katzman, Sei Lee, Brie Williams, and Alex Smith), 2 core laboratories (analytic, headed by Chuck McCulloch and John Boscardin, and measurement, headed by Mike Steinman, Anita Stewartt, and Anna Napoles), and 4 pilot projects (submitted by Emily Finlayson, Margot Kushel, Rebecca Sudore, and Victor Valcour).   Center leadership includes Seth Landefeld (PI), Ken Covinksy, Eliseo Perez-Stable, Janice Schwartz, Jackie Leung, Louise Walter, and Kristine Yaffe.  And none of this would have happened without Joanne Dang, who shepherded the application through to submission with exceptional competence and commitment.

 
The Division of Geriatrics submits a competitive renewal application to the John A. Hartford Foundation
The Division of Geriatrics has hosted a highly rated John A. Hartford Foundation Center of Excellence (CoE) in Academic Geriatrics since 1998.  The just-submitted competitive renewal application proposed 8 junior faculty and fellows as Hartford Scholars – Helen Kao, Sei Lee, John Newman, Carla Perissinotto, Alex Smith, Margarita Sotelo, Eric Widera, and Brie Williams – in the hopes that other faculty and fellows will join their ranks in the next year.  The mentors for our proposed Hartford Scholars include Louise Aronson, John Boscardin, Ken Covinsky, Mike Harper, Bree Johnston, Seth Landefeld, Edgar Pierluissi, and Louise Walter.  Joanne Dang pulled our crew together and made sure everything came together on time and on target.
Geriatric News Items for the week of November 22, 2010
Seth Landfeld gives Grand Rounds and visits several locations accross the country

Wheres Seth Landefeld been?  Its been like trying to find Waldo, except without the beanie.  Between submitting an application for an Older Americans Independence Center to the NIA and the Center of Excellence renewal to the Hartford Foundation, hes visited our colleagues and given Grand Rounds at Harvard and the Beth Israel-Deaconess (BID), Brown and Rhode Island Hospital, the UK, Mt. Sinai, and the Regional Geriatric Program of Toronto.  Heres his story: 

At the Beth Israel, I gave the Harold Solomon Lecture in Preventive Medicine, in honor of Dr. Solomon, a bow-tie aficianado and donor of the tie now in my office (pictured to the left).  At Brown, I gave the 24th Sidney Katz Annual Lecture in honor of the man who developed the Index of ADL and mentored both Ken Covinsky and me.  At the British Geriatrics Society Annual Meeting, I caught up with Graham Mulley, who visited us 2 years ago, and gave the Trevor Howell Memorial Lecture.  At Sinai, I got to know many of their wonderful faculty and fellows and came home with some great ideas for our fellowship.  And in Toronto, I have found the source of Loyal she began, loyal she remains – youll have to come to my UCSF Geriatric Grand Rounds on December 1 to find out.
 
Mike Steinman is JAMA's Author in the Room
Mike Steinman was JAMAs Author in the Room this week, speaking about his recent article, Managing Medications in Clinically Complex Elders:  Theres Got to Be a Happy Medium.  Mike was almost off the charts:  he hit #2 in the all-time-hit list for Author in the Room, which JAMA and IHI have hosted for years.  Congratulations, Mike!  As they say, the hits just keep on coming.
 
Louise Aronson, MD, MFA authors two articles

Louise Aronson, MD MFA, authored two recent articles on reflective learning in medical education. One study demonstrated that learners reflective skill - which correlates with lifelong learning and professionalism - can be assessed independent of their writing or storytelling skills, and the second provided a literature-based guide to the design, implementation and evaluation of reflective learning curricula. Dr. Aronson was selected to present this work at the recent Association of American Medical Colleges annual meeting. Read articles:

Writing and Storytelling Article
Twelve tips for teaching reflection
 
NorCal GEC and the Center for Vulnerable Populations at SFGH offer a course on the care of socially complex vulnerable elders

For three Tuesdays in November, the Northern California Geriatrics Education Center (GEC) partnered with the Center for Vulnerable Populations (CVP) at San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center to offer an interprofessional, continuing education course on the care of socially complex vulnerable elders. Co-Chairs Louise Aronson, MD, MFA [hyperlink] and Neda Ratanawongsa, MD, MPH led a dynamic faculty roster of 18 local experts, including the Divisions own Mike Harper, MD, Helen Kao, MD, Carla Perissinotto, MD, MHS, Edgar Pierluissi, MD, Josette Rivera, MD, Margarita Sotelo, MD, and Eric Widera, MD.

The innovative educational program consisted of team teaching by physicians, nurses, social workers, and pharmacists, setting of course and session-specific practice and learning goals, and dynamic case discussions to consolidate material from multiple sessions. The enthusiastic participation of clinical teams from the San Francisco Health Plan, San Francisco General Hospital, Catholic Health Care West, Santa Clara Valley Medical Center and the East Bay Community Health Center Network more than quadrupled the anticipated enrollment. Thanks to the flawless planning and execution by Cary Speidell, Joan Abrams, Adam Moylan (GEC) and Natalie Collins (CVP), the program received highly positive ratings and comments from participants, including: This has already changed my practice so much; Usually at courses, as an NP I feel like a second-class citizen; this course made me feel like an equal team member; and I realized I was stuck in some ruts and I am excited to provide much better care.

More information, including the full faculty roster, can be viewed here

Vivien Sun, is one of four recipients of the 2010-11 Deans Prize in Research
UCSF MSTAR student, Vivien Sun, is one of four recipients of the 2010-11 Deans Prize in Research for her work she completed this summer with Dr. Brie Williams. Vivien presented on the research that she accomplished last summer in the Division of Geriatrics related to the association between neighborhood safety and functional decline and death in older Americans.
 
Division faculty represent at the first American Board of Medical Specialties board examination
Palliative Medicine has arrived bigtime in the UCSF Division of Geriatrics.  A whole pride of UCSF Geriatrics faculty recently sat for the first American Board of Medical Specialties board examination in its new specialty of Palliative Medicine.  We are proud of Drs. Bree Johnston, Helen Kao, Sandra Moody, Carla Perissinotto, Alex Smith, Rebecca Sudore, and Sei Lee – all of whom we know hit the ball out of the park.  We will follow their experience on www.geripal.org!
 
GeriPals content is viewed a total of 200,000 times
GeriPal is quickly becoming the go-to online source for geriatrics and palliative care news and commentary.   GeriPals content has been now viewed a total of 200,000 times – an amazing number considering the site was only conceived of a year and a half ago by Alex Smith and Eric Widera.   These views currently include 98,000 pageviews from people visiting our site and an additional 103,000 views by people reading our posts by email or feed readers. 
 
Maxine Davis receives a Great People Award

Maxine Davis, Division Administrator, received a Great People Award in recognition of her continued dedication, ability to inspire others and her accomplishments.  Her work serves as a model for exhibiting qualities and values essential to making the UCSF School of Medicine a great place to work. 

Visit the School of Medicine website to nominate a co-worker for his/her contributions towards making UCSF a great place to work; next deadline is December 1, 2010.
Geriatric News Items for the week of November 8, 2010
Theresa Allison receives her PhD from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
Theresa Allison, MD (Assistant Professor and Associate Medical Director, Jewish Home of San Francisco) will receive her PhD on December 20 from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Theresa completed her dissertation during and after her Geriatrics Fellowship at UCSF. It is titled Transcending the Limitations of Aging through Music: Ethnomusicology in the Nursing Home. You can hear a clip of a Jewish Home original composition, "I'm a Hundred Years Old," at www.songwritingworks.org.
 
Michael Steinman, MD is accepted to the UCSF CORO Faculty Leadership Initiative
Michael Steinman, MD was accepted to the UCSF CORO Faculty Leadership Initiative, a leadership training program for UCSF faculty.  The training is conducted by the Coro Center for Civic Leadership, a nationally-known leadership training organization based in San Francisco. The aim of this initiative is to catalyze individual and collective change which benefits the broader UCSF community.
 
Dr. Steinman is Author in the Room for a national conference call
Michael Steinman, MD will be scheduled by JAMA. The topic of the call will be about his recent article in that journal on medication prescribing for older adults.
Geriatric News Items for the week of November 1, 2010
Vivien Sun is on of 8 finalists for the UCSF Dean's Research Prize
UCSF MSTAR student, Vivien Sun, has been named as one of the 8 finalists for the UCSF Dean's Research Prize for her work she completed this summer with Dr. Brie Williams. Vivien moves on to the next stage in the competition where she will present on the research that she accomplished last summer in the Division of Geriatrics related to the association between neighborhood safety and functional decline and death in older Americans.
 
Two new team members for GeriTraCCC

The UCSF Division of Geriatrics is excited to announce two new team members who began working with our geriatric clinical services today.

Gary Winter, LCSW, joins our Housecalls and Geriatric Transitions, Consultation, and Comprehensive Care (GeriTraCCC) practice bringing a wealth of knowledge in his work at San Francisco General Hospitals Department of Psychiatry and in prior work with the SFGH Emergency Department case management program. Gary is a strong patient advocate who will be providing critical psychosocial support to complex and frail patients in Housecalls and GeriTraCCC.

Kirby Lee, PharmD, who has long been a partner with our Division in a variety of clinical and teaching programs, joins the new GeriTraCCC practice as a volunteer clinical pharmacist. He will be working with the GeriTraCCC team once a month to help patients experiencing challenges with their medications—eg. difficulty managing multiple medications, possible side effects and/or drug interactions.

Both Gary and Kirby have experience in program development and we look forward to their collaboration and input as we build the Model Geriatric Practice for the aging century.
 
Call for a national strategic plan to stop Alzheimers disease by 2020
In a recent Op-Ed piece for the New York Times (NYT 10/28/10), Sandra Day O'Connor (retired associate justice of the Supreme Court), Stanley Prusiner (Director, Institute for Neurodegenerative Diseases at UCSF and recipient of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Medicine) and Ken Dychtwald (consultant to businesses about the aging world population) call for a national strategic plan to stop Alzheimers disease by 2020. They emphasize that Alzheimers is both incurable and fatal, and presents a looming threat to our nations health in light of the 79 million baby boomers who begin turning 65 in 2011 at the rate of one every eight seconds.
 
Alexander Smith, MD is quoted in US News and World Report
Alexander Smith, MD was quoted in the November 1 online issue of the US News and World Report article titled, Almost Half of Elderly Report Pain in Life's Final Months Dr. Smith is quoted regarding his study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine that examines the prevalence and correlates of pain during the last 2 years of life. Smith said, "This study shows that there's a substantial burden of pain at the end of life, and not just the very end of life." This article was also discussed in the Los Angeles Times.  Dr. Smith is Assistant Professor of Medicine in the Division of Geriatrics, UCSF and Staff Physician, SFVAMC. UCSF Division of Geriatrics faculty Eric Widera, Brie Williams, John Boscardin, Irena Stajicic Cenzar, and Ken Covinsky were co-authors on the paper. 
Geriatric News Items for the week of October 18, 2010
Eric Widera, MD is featured in the New York Times
Eric Widera, MD, an Assistant Professor in the Division of Geriatrics was featured in the October 14 New York Times article, "The Doctor Is In (but Shouldnt Be)".  Dr. Widera discusses issues surrounding health care professionals who work rather than stay home when they're ill.  The article cites a recent publication from Dr. Widera, Dr. Anna Chang, and Dr Helen Chen on the topic of Presenteeism that was published recently in the Journal of General Internal Medical.
 
Brie Williams, MD, MS is the Division of Geriatrics first Lieberman Scholar
Brie Williams, MD, MS, an Assistant Professor in the Division of Geriatrics, will be the Divisions first Lieberman Scholar. This two-year award will support Dr. Williams project entitled "Vulnerable older adults who come into contact with the legal system: a cross-cultural perspective. Dr. Williams will showcase the results of her research at a Grand Rounds presentation during the 2011-2012 academic year. The award is made possible by a generous gift to the UCSF/Mt. Zion Center on Aging from the Lieberman family in honor of their father, Dr. Benjamin Lieberman, and to support geriatrics from multicultural perspectives.
 
Char Carlson, MD and Louise Walter, MD study the follow-up of fecal occult blood testing
Char Carlson, MD (MSTAR student and current UCSF Intern) worked with Louise Walter, MD (senior author) to study the follow-up of fecal occult blood testing (2010) in 2,410 older adults screened at 4 VA facilities. Additional authors include Kate Kirby (Statistician); Michele Casadei (RA) and Chrissy Kistler (Geriatrics Fellow and now faculty at UNC). Read Article
Geriatric News Items for the Week of October 11, 2010
Michael Steinman, MD authors an article in JAMA
Michael Steinman, MD authored an article in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Using the case of an older patient taking multiple medications, this article summarizes the evidence-based literature about improving medication use and withdrawing specific drugs and drug classes. It also describes a systematic approach for how health professionals can assess and improve medication regimens to benefit patients and their caregivers and families. Read Article

Dr. Brie Williams Publishes an Article in JGIM
Dr. Brie Williams published an article in Journal for General Internal Medicine titled, Coming Home: Health Status and Homelessness Risk of Older Pre-release Prisoners. News Items for the week of September 20, 2010
Maxine Davis is selected for the Leadership Development Program
Maxine Davis, Division Administrator, has been selected to participate in the 2010-2011 School of Medicines Leadership Development Program. 

The Leadership Development Program provides an opportunity for a select group of individuals to enhance their careers in the School of Medicine and for the School to expand the pool of well-qualified candidates ready for advancement.
 

Four Division of Geriatrics Faculty Receive HRSA Geriatric Academic Career Awards

We are pleased to announce that Drs. Helen Kao, Josette Rivera, Carla Perissinotto and Margarita Sotelo have all received HRSA Geriatric Academic Career Awards (GACA)! The purpose of the GACA is to increase the number of junior faculty at accredited schools of allopathic and osteopathic medicine and to promote the development of their careers as academic geriatricians who emphasize training in clinical geriatrics including the training of interdisciplinary teams of health professionals.

Dr. Rivera will focus on Interprofessional Geriatric Medical Education

Dr. Perissinotto will focus on Multisite Geriatric Training for Primary Care Residents

Dr. Kao will focus on Academic-Community Partnerships for a Model Geriatric Practice for Integrated Care and Teaching

Dr. Sotelo will focus on Improving Hospital Care through Education and Interdisciplinary Collaboration

 
Michael Steinman, MD is quoted in the New York Times

Michael Steinman, MD was quoted in the September 21 issue of the New York Times article titled, "Web Tool to Check Heart Risk Is Doubted Dr. Steinman is quoted regarding his study that examines the difference between the original and simplified versions of a heart attack risk calculator. Steinman said, "People were told that for clinical purposes either one of the formulas could be used, that they were interchangeable. Our study highlights that there can be meaningful differences for individual patients."

Dr. Steinman is Associate Professor of Medicine in the Division of Geriatrics, UCSF and Staff Physician, SFVAMC.

Candy Crider, RN, MSN ia selected for VA Secretary for Health's Award for Innovation in VA Community Living Centers.
Candy Crider, RN, MSN has been selected for the first VA Under Secretary for Health's Award for Innovation in VA Community Living Centers. Kala Mehta, DSc and Brie Williams, MD are winners of the mentor of the year award
Division faculty Kala Mehta, DSc and Brie Williams, MD were selected as co-winners of the mentor of the year award for the Medical School Training in Aging Research (MSTAR) program at UCSF.   Dr. Mehta mentored Sangeeta Kalsi, a rising second-year medical student at UCLA, on research investigating racial and ethnic differences in functional decline in older adults.  Dr. Williams mentored Vivien Sun, a rising second-year medical student at UCSF, on research evaluating the relationship between perceived neighborhood safety and functional decline in older people.
 
Harris Fishbon Distinguished Professorship
The Department of Medicine, Division of Geriatrics Search Committee is actively reviewing candidates from across the country to serve as the first Harris Fishbon Distinguished Professor for Clinical Translational Research in Aging. The Fishbon Distinguished Professor will lead the development of a research program in the Division of Geriatrics at UCSF that will improve the care and health of very old persons through the translation of research findings to clinical benefits in people with diseases associated with very old age. The Fishbon Distinguished Professorship is supported by a $2.5 million endowment established by the Harris Fishbon Fund of the Mt. Zion Health Fund and the Jewish Home of San Francisco (JHSF).  For more information, please contact: Elaine Chow
Geriatric News Items for the week of August 23, 2010
Sharon Kaufman, PhD authors an article in Perspectives in Biology and Medicine

Sharon Kaufman, PhD from the UCSF Institute for Health and Aging authored an article in Perspectives in Biology and Medicine titled, Making Longevity in an Aging Society Linking Medicare Policy and the New Ethical Field. In this article, Dr. Kaufman discusses how life-extending interventions for older persons are changing medical knowledge and societal expectations about longevity. This article is the written version of the Lieberman lecture Dr. Kaufman delivered on October 13, 2009.

The Benjamin Lieberman, MD Lectureship is a biennial affair focused on issues of aging and gerontology. This event is sponsored by the UCSF-Mt. Zion Center on Aging, is supported by a generous gift from Dr. E. James Lieberman, Mrs. Marcia Popper and Mrs. Ediera Plotinsky, in honor of their father, Dr. Benjamin Lieberman.

October 13, 2010 from 12:30 pm to 5:00 pm

Visiting Professor Zhongcong Xie, Director of the Geriatric Anesthesia Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School, joins several prominent UCSF clinicians and investigators to discuss the pathophysiology of cognitive decline and how factors such as surgery and anesthesia may affect this phenomenon.

Program information and registration is available at the Cognitive Decline Symposium wiki
 

Anne Kelly, MSW and Alexander Smith, MD, MS, MPH co authored an article

Anne Kelly, MSW, a social worker at the SFVAMC and Alexander Smith, MD, MS, MPH Assistant Professor in the Division of Geriatrics co authored an article titled, "Length of Stay for Older Adults Residing in Nursing Homes at the End of Life." The study found that lengths of stay for older adults residing in nursing homes at the end of life are surprisingly brief – less than six months for over half of decedents.

UCSF Press Release
 
Louise Aronson, MD, MFA is selected for the 2010 Teaching Excellence Award from UCSFs Haile Debas Academy of Medical Educators
Louise Aronson, MD, MFA has been selected for a 2010 Teaching Excellence Award from UCSFs Haile Debas Academy of Medical Educators.  The Academys Excellence in Teaching Awards are peer-nominated and intended to highlight outstanding front-line teachers of medical students and residents at all UCSF teaching sites.  Louise has taught especially effectively in Foundations of Patient Care and UCSF Housecalls, and is a leader in studying and developing curricula for critical reflection in medical education.  Louise Aronson is Associate Professor of Medicine in the Division of Geriatrics, PI of the HRSA-funded Northern California Geriatrics Education Center, and Director of UCSFs Pathways to Discovery.
Geriatric News Items for the week of August 16, 2010
Improving Quality of Care for Socially Complex and Vulnerable Elders Course

Improving Quality of Care for Socially Complex and Vulnerable Elders is a course that will be held at UCSF Laurel Heights on November 2, 9 and 16.

This case-based, interactive course is designed for physicians, nurses, social workers, psychologists, pharmacists, and other health professionals who work with the underserved and are interested in improving the quality of care for their geriatric patients. Participants will learn practical, evidence-based approaches to enhance care for diverse, socially complex and
medically vulnerable elders and how to balance the evidence with a patient-centered approach in order to maximize function and achieve goals of care. View brochure
 
Dr. Kristine Yaffee receives the Dr. J. Elliott Royer Award in Psychiatry for Academic Excellence
Kristine Yaffe, MD, has received the 2010 Dr. J. Elliott Royer Award in Psychiatry for Academic Excellence. The Royer Award honors Bay Area physicians who have made significant contributions to the fields of psychiatry and neurology. She was cited for her extraordinary contributions to the field of geriatric psychiatry, national and international recognition as an expert on cognitive function and dementia in the elderly, and contributions as a superb mentor and an outstanding clinician. Dr. Yaffe is Chief of Geriatric Psychiatry at the San Francisco VA Medical Center and Associate Chair of Clinical and Translational Research in the Department of Psychiatry and Professor of Psychiatry, Neurology, and Epidemiology at the University of California, San Francisco. She was recently named the first holder of the Roy and Marie Scola Endowed Chair in Psychiatry in the Department of Psychiatry.
 
Geriatric News Items for the Week of August 9, 2010
Louise Aronson, MD, MFA is elected to the Haile T. Debas Academy of Medical Educators
Louise Aronson, MD, MFA has been elected to The Haile T. Debas Academy of Medical Educators – one of only 7 UCSF faculty elected this year.  Renowned as an innovator in medical education, an inspiring teacher and mentor, an increasingly recognized medical education researcher, and a delightful writer, Dr. Aronson directs the Northern California Geriatrics Education Center and UCSFs Pathways to Discovery program.  She also leads the Aging and Palliative Care Student Interest Group and co-directs UCSF Medical Humanities.  Dr. Aronson joins 3 other Division faculty (Bree Johnston, MD, MPH, Mike Harper, MD, and Anna Chang, MD) as Academy members.  An Associate Professor of Medicine, Dr. Aronson was the first geriatrics fellow in the Division of Geriatrics and the Founding Director of UCSF HouseCalls.  Celebrate Louse Aronsons election to the Academy on Monday September 20, 3:30-5PM in N-225 on the Parnassus Campus.
 
UCSF is 1 of only 10 medical schools that was awarded grants for both a Geriatric Education Center and a Geriatrics Training Program

UCSF is 1 of only 10 medical schools that was awarded grants for both a Geriatric Education Center and a Geriatrics Training Program by the US Department of Health and Human Services, according to the recent announcement by HHS Secretary Kathleen Sebelius . 

UCSFs Northern California Geriatrics Education Center is led by Louise Aronson, MD, MFA (Associate Professor of Medicine) and the Geriatrics Training Program for Physicians, Dentists, and Mental Health Professionals is led by Michael Harper, MD (Associate Professor of Medicine and ACOS/Geriatrics, Palliative, and Extended Care at San Francisco VAMC).  Each award is for ~$500,000/yr.

Geriatric News Items for the Week of August 2, 2010
GeriTraCCC Launches!

 

On Monday, August 2, 2010, the new UCSF Geriatric Transitions, Consultation, and Comprehensive Care practice opened its doors.

The goals of GeriTraCCC are to improve the care of frail older adults and help them and their caregivers achieve the greatest well-being. The practice will provide two valuable services: 1) comprehensive geriatric consultations for older adults, and 2) geriatric post-discharge care for older heart failure patients returning home from the hospital.

HRSA grants a 5-year renewal of Geriatric Division Training Programs
The Health Resources and Services Administration has granted a 5-year renewal of the Divisions Geriatric Training Program For Physicians, Dentists, and Behavioral and Mental Health Professions. Geriatric News Items for the week of June 21, 2010
Robert A. Petzel, MD visits SFVAMC and declares the CLC best in the country
Robert A. Petzel, M.D., Under Secretary for Health in the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), visited San Francisco VAMC on Tuesday June 22 and declared its Community Living Center (CLC) the best CLC in the country.

The CLC provides exemplary long-term care for 100 disabled veterans in a village setting on the SFVAMC campus. The CLC is led by Anna Chang, MD (Associate Professor of Geriatrics and Medical Director), Candice Crider, MS, RN (Associate Chief Nurse), and Anne Johnson, LCSW (Associate Director, Geriatrics and Extended Care Service).
 
Erwin Tan, a graduate of the UCSF Geriatrics Fellowship is named Director of Senior Corps
Erwin Tan, a graduate of the UCSF Geriatrics Fellowship and the VA Quality Scholars Fellowship will be joining the Obama administration as Director of Senior Corps!

Senior Corps is a sister organization of AmeriCorps in the Corporation for National and Community Service (a federal agency). It has a budget of $220 million and runs three programs: Foster Grandparents, Retired Senior Volunteer Program, and Senior Companion Program. More information can be found at www.seniorcorps.gov.

Erwin did his fellowship training in the Geriatrics Division after completing the SFGH Primary Care Residency, during which he was voted by his peers to receive the Jeff Weingarten Memorial Award for compassionate care of patients. After his training, Erwin was the recipient of a prestigious White House Fellowship. Over the past few years, he has been on the Geriatrics faculty at Johns Hopkins where he has played a leadership role in the Experience Corp Study.

All of Erwin's friends and colleagues in the UCSF Geriatrics Division wish him well as he continues his impressive history of public service in this vital leadership position.
Geriatric News Items for the week of May 31, 2010
Alexander Smith, MD has received the Greenwall Faculty Scholars Award in Bioethics.
Alexander Smith, MD has received the Greenwall Faculty Scholars Award in Bioethics. This is a three year career development award focused on normative ethical work that influences public policy and clinical practice. Dr. Smith's work will focus on ethical issues in patient-surrogate-clinician conversations about prognosis for frail elders from diverse communities. His primary mentor for this award is Dr. Bernard Lo, Professor of Medicine, UCSF.
 
Candice Crider was named as a national finalists for the Under Secretary for Healths Award
Candice Crider, RN MSN (Associate Chief of Nursing Service, Geriatrics and Extended Care, SFVAMC) was named one of two national finalists for the Under Secretary for Healths Award for Innovation in VA Community Living Centers at the VA Cultural Transformation Conference! This national award recognizes a single individual who exhibits the highest standards of excellence, dedication, and accomplishment in transforming the culture of a VA CLC and who demonstrates innovation in the approach to care that stewards human and financial resources responsibly, nurtures the spirit of the Veterans served, and improves the quality of care and quality of life provided in a VA CLC.  
 
The Community Living Center (CLC) wins further recognition for its excellence
The Community Living Center (CLC), the site at San Francisco VAMC for long-term, hospice, and sub-acute care provided by Geriatrics faculty and staff, has won further recognition for its excellence. Mr. Lawrence H. Carroll, Director of SFVAMC, recently wrote: Our Community Living Center is an excellent example of care and service that is patient-centered. They have embraced the cultural transformation concept and are working hard to make the CLC a home for our Veteran residents. In the coming months you will hear more about the Medical Home model. This program will be transforming how we provide patient care, focusing on the team concept. THIS TEAM RECEIVED A 2010 NATIONAL VA POSTER AWARD (SECOND PLACE) FOR ITS INNOVATIVE PROJECTS. The CLC is staffed by outstanding nurses, doctors, and other professionals, all under the leadership of Anna Chang, MD (Medical Director and Assistant Professor), Candy Crider, RN (Director, Nursing), and Anne Johnson, MSW (Director, Social Services).
 
Rebecca Conant presented a poster that was awarded the Presidential Poster Award
At the annual American Geriatrics Society meeting in Orlando FL this year, Rebecca Conant presented a poster that was awarded the Presidential Poster Award. The poster was entitled Interdisciplinary Team Training Improves Geriatric Knowledge and Attitudes Concerning Older Adults and Teams. The authors included Susan Hyde from the UCSF School of Dentistry, Lynda Mackin from the UCSF School of Nursing, Kirby Lee from the UCSF School of Pharmacy, Adam Moylan from the School of Medicine and Eva Schmitt from the Institute on Aging. The work was sponsored by the Academic Geriatric Resource Program and HRSA.
 
  UCSF internal medicine residents are selected to participate in the SCEGM Award Summit
UCSF internal medicine residents Dr. Dandan Liu and Dr. Anna Chodos were nominated and selected by the leadership of the Southeast Center of Excellence in Geriatric Medicine (SCEGM) to participate in the 7th Annual SCEGM Resident Award Summit. The event was held on  May 21 and 22, 2010 on the campus of The University of Alabama at Birmingham. The SCEGM, a joint program of Emory University and the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB), was established in 1998 to promote the career development of physicians as clinician educators and researchers. Congratulations Drs. Liu and Chodos!
Geriatric News Items for the week of May 17, 2010
Bree Johnston, MD, MPH is elected to the ABIM Subspecialty Board on Geriatric Medicine
Bree Johnston, MD, MPH was elected to the eight member ABIM Subspecialty Board on Geriatric Medicine for a two year term that will commence on July 1, 2010.   Among her responsibilities will be development of the secure geriatrics examination that all diplomates must pass in order to be certified as a Geriatrician.
Geriatric News Items for the week of May 3, 2010
Jessamyn Connell-Price is accepted to medical school

Jessamyn Conell-Price Research Assistant in the Division of Geriatrics has been accepted to medical school! Starting this summer, Jessamyn will be enrolled in the UCSF-UC Berkeley Joint Medical Program (JMP). The JMP is innovative partnership between our two campuses that focuses on small group learning and the intersection between the social sciences and humanities. It is one of the most competitive medical education programs in the US. Two Division of Geriatrics faculty, Bree Johnston, and Alex Smith are alumni of the JMP.

Congratulations Jessamyn! We await your entry into the 2019 Division of Geriatrics Fellowship Class!
 
  Louise Aronson is presented with the Pathways to Discovery Mentor Award
Louise Aronson, MD, MFA, was awarded a Pathways to Discovery Mentor Award for providing the vision, curriculum development, and teaching of communication skills necessary to lead in health sciences and healthcare to the programs students and residents. The Pathways program facilitates motivated learners in developing the knowledge, skills, and experience to contribute to health beyond the care of individual patients in areas of specialization including health research, curriculum and education theory development, policy and advocacy, and other interventions to improve health on a global scale.
 
Char Carlson is mentored by Louise Walter and wins award for most outstanding poster
Char Carlson (Medical Student 4 and incoming UCSF Internal Medicine Resident) won the award for Most Outstanding Poster at the Pathways to Discovery Symposium for her research on "Lack of Follow-up after Fecal Occult Blood Testing in Older Adults: Inappropriate Screening or Failure to Follow-up?"

This award is given to the graduating UCSF medical student with the most outstanding research poster in the Pathways program. Louise Walter (Associate Professor) mentored Ms. Carlson.
 
Dr. Dan Blazer is the keynote speaker for Geriatric Grand Rounds for May 2010
We are proud to be hosting Dr. Dan Blazer as our keynote speaker for Geriatric Grand Rounds for May 2010. Dr. Blazer is the J.P. Gibbons Professor of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences in the Division of Community and Family Medicine, School of Medicine, at the Duke University Institute for Brain Sciences. He will be speaking on "Lessons from the Epidemiology of Substance Use Disorders in Later Life".
 
Dr. Sudore is selected to present her work in a plenary session at the 2010 SGIM Meeting

Dr. Rebecca Sudore was selected to present her work in a plenary session at the 2010 Annual Meeting of the Society of General Internal Medicine.  For her study entitled, The Clash Between Advance Directive Law and Clinical Care: Ramifications for Vulnerable Populations, she reviewed all 50 states advance directive laws and reviewed court case rulings. The study demonstrated that state advance directive laws can create substantial barriers to patients who want to engage in advance care planning, articulate their preferences for medical care, and have their wishes honored at the end-of-life.

Dr. Sudore is Assistant Professor of Medicine in the Division of Geriatrics and Health Services Research and Development Career Development Awardee at the San Francisco VA Medical Center.
 
Dr. Aronson's Students win theStudent Poster Award at WGEA Meeting
Dr. Louise Aronsons students Christopher Bautista, Mellody Hayes and Jennifer Stella won the student poster award at the meeting of the Association of American Medical Colleges Western Group on Educational Affairs (WGEA). This award is presented to the undergraduate students who submit the most outstanding student abstract and poster. The selection committee noted that this groups selection was unanimous.
 
Dr. Anna Chang takes the UCSF Foundations of Patient Care Course to new heights
Dr. Anna Chang (Assistant Professor) has led the UCSF Foundations of Patient Care (FPC) Course for the 2009-10 academic year.  During Dr. Changs first year as course director, the phenomenal FPC team broke a record earning the highest overall course ratings in the history of the course!  On a scale of 1 (poor) to 5 (excellent), UCSF students gave the course an overall course rating of 4.12, accompanied by an increase in every single measured component of the course.  Congratulations to the team of dedicated teachers and staff!
 
AGS selects Jennie Chin Hansen, RN, MSN, FAAN as its new Chief Executive Officer
The American Geriatrics Society (AGS) has chosen AARP President Jennie Chin Hansen, RN, MSN, FAAN, as its new Chief Executive Officer. Ms. Hansen is a long-standing friend of UCSF.  She graduated from UCSFs School of Nursing, is currently a Senior Fellow, and has advised the Division of Geriatrics since its founding in 1997.  She served previously as CEO of San Franciscos On Lok and led its development as a pioneering model of comprehensive care for frail elders.
 
Dr. Helen Kao is the 2010-2011 recipient of the Betty and James E. Birren Emerging Leadership Award
Helen Kao, MD has been selected as the 2010- 2011 recipient of the Betty and James E. Birren Emerging Leadership Award in recognition of your scholastic accomplishments in the field of gerontology and geriatrics.  Dr. Kao is renowned for her groundbreaking work integrating geriatrics education, care, and service in the community through her practice at the Over60 Clinic in Berkeley.  The Birren Emerging Leadership Award is made by the California Council on Gerontology and Geriatrics in a statewide competition.
Geriatric news items for the week of February 15, 2010
Drs. Walter and Mehta's article highlighted in Newsweek
Louise Walter's and Kala Mehta's recent article in AJPH regarding mammogram screening among elderly women with dementia is featured in the NY Times article "Mammograms and Severe Dementia." Their co-authors were Anna Chang, MD (Assistant Professor), Chrissy Kistler, MD (Geriatrics Fellow), and Kathy Fung, MS (Analyst).

NY Times article , AJPH article
 
Seth Landefeld, MD is interviewed by KCBS regarding feeding tube use on dementia patients
Chief of UCSF's Division of Geriatrics Dr. Seth Landefeld says using feeding tubes for people with severe dementia does not solve the nutrition issues facing these patients. Dr. Landefeld was interviewed by KCBS about a recent paper in the February 10 issue of JAMA, Hospital Characteristics Associated With Feeding Tube Placement in Nursing Home Residents With Advanced Cognitive Impairment. The interview can be heard at Patient care.
Geriatric news items for the week of February 8, 2010
Mark V. Williams, MD, FACP, FHM is the keynote speaker at the Division of Geriatrics Grand Rounds
Mark V. Williams, MD, FACP, FHM, Professor and Chief of the Division of Hospital Medicine at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine was this year's Reynolds Visiting Professor and the keynote speaker at the Division of Geriatrics Grand Rounds on February 10, 2010. The title of Dr. Williams' talk was "BOOSTing the Hospital Discharge Transition".
 
Dr. Smith receives the AGS New Invesitgator Award
Alex Smith, MD has received an American Geriatrics Society New Investigator Award. Dr. Smith received the award for his research in emergency department use at the end-of-life.  This award will be conferred at the Annual Meeting of the American Geriatrics Society in Orlando, FL in May.
 
Dr. Walter's MSTAR student is recipient of the 2010 AGS Clinical Student Research Award
Louise Walter's MSTAR student Cynthia So has been selected the recipient of the 2010 American Geriatrics Society Clinical Student Research Award. This award is presented to undergraduate students who submitted the most outstanding student abstract for the 2010 AGS Annual Scientific Meeting.
 
Drs. Chin-Garcia, Hsu and Perissinotto posters are all accepted to the AGS Presidential Poster Session
Congratulations to Geriatrics Fellows Carie Chin-Garcia, Angela Hsu and Carla Perissinotto who all had posters accepted to the Presidential Poster Session at AGS this year.
Geriatric news for the week of February 1, 2010
Louise Walter, MD receives the 2010 Distinction in Mentoring Award
Louise Walter, MD (Associate Professor) has received the 2010 Distinction In Mentoring Award from the Academic Senate.  Recipients of the Academic Senate Distinction In Teaching Awards and the Distinction In Mentoring Awards will be honored by the Chancellor at the annual Founders Day Banquet on April 29, and in Academic Senate Distinguished Faculty Awards Ceremony to be held April 14, 2010 at 3:30 p.m. in Cole Hall.
Geriatric news items for the week of January 25, 2010
Drs. Hsu and Kao coauthor a letter to editor in the New England Journal of Medicine
Angela Hsu, MD (Clinical Fellow in Geriatrics) and Helen Kao, MD (Assistant Professor) coauthored a letter to the editor in the January 28, 2010 issue of the New England Journal of Medicine in response to Mitchell et. al.s October 15, 2009 article, The clinical course of advanced dementia. Their letter pointed out the importance of advanced directives for providing care congruent with the values of patients with end-stage dementia as expressed by these patients or their proxies.  Read Letter
Geriatric news items for the week of January 18, 2010
Drs. Johnston and Harper receive funding to develop the ACE Plus Program at the SFVAMC
Congratulations to C. Bree Johnston, MD, MPH and Mike Harper, MD for the funding of their $650,000 proposal to develop the "ACE Plus Program" at San Francisco VAMC! The award is an exceptional tribute to their vision and work.This grant will have a major impact on the care of older veterans, the education of medical students and residents, and the professional lives of many involved professionals.  Thank you, Bree and Mike, on behalf of all of us.
Geriatric news for the week of February 1, 2010
Division of Geriatrics hosts a presentation by Cheryl L. Phillips, MD, AGSF, CMD

The UCSF Division of Geriatrics was proud to host a special presentation by Cheryl L. Phillips, MD, AGSF, CMD. Dr. Phillips is Chief Medical Officer of OnLok Lifeways in San Francisco, CA and President of the American Geriatrics Society. On Wednesday, January 13, 2010, Dr. Phillips presented "Beyond the Health Care Reform Debate: Looking to 2010 and Beyond" to a group of over 30 physicians, fellows, nurses, social workers and other allied health professionals at the San Francisco VA Medical Center.

View flyer
Geriatric news items for the week of January 4, 2010
JAMA launched a new series that is produced and edited in the Division of Geriatrics

Welcome to the Aging Century!  On December 30, JAMA launched a new series, Care of the Aging Patient: From Evidence to Action, that is produced and edited in the Division of Geriatrics by Seth Landefeld (senior editor), Helen Chen and Louise Walter (co-editors), Amy Markowitz (managing editor), and Phil Tiso (editorial assistant).  The overall goal of this series will be to help improve clinical practice and inform policy in care of older individuals, especially those who have started to lose their independence or are at risk of doing so.  

In the first article in the series, David Reuben, M.D., of the University of California, Los Angeles, discusses the approach to care of older patients beginning with a consideration of life expectancy and patient goals.  An accompanying commentary by Christine Cassel, M.D., President of the American Board of Internal Medicine, addresses necessary changes in workforce support for primary care, training requirements, payment reform, research, and systems to improve care of older adults.  An accompanying editorial sets the stage for the series in the Aging Century, when average lifespan may reach 100 years in some countries and individuals aged 85 years or older are the most rapidly increasing segment of many populations.

Aticle: Medical Care in the Final Years of Life
Commentary: Policy for an Aging Society
Editorial: Clinical Care in the Aging Century
 
Cultural Transformation of the Community Living Center at The SFVAMC
The Division of Geriatrics faculty have implemented tax-deductable donations to a special fund earmarked to pay for Cultural Transformation to the Community Living Center, the long-term care facility at San Francisco VA Medical Center. Gifts will be used to pay for items or services that will promote a homelike, non-institutional culture, the VA may be traditionally prohibited from purchasing. For example, the Cultural Transformation Fund will pay for veterinary care of a resident pet, aquarium service, etc.
 
Helen Kao, MD was lead author in an editorial in the Archives of Internal Medicine
Helen Kao, MD (Asst Professor) was lead author on an editorial in the most recent issue of the Archives of Internal Medicine.  The editorial discussed innovative approaches to improving hospital care for the elderly such as the hospital at home model.  Louise Walter, MD (Assoc Professor) was senior author on the editorial.
 
Drs. Sudore and Walter attended the RWJ Physician Faculty Scholars Program 2009 National Meeting
Rebecca Sudore, MD (Asst Professor) and Louise Walter, MD (Assoc Professor) attended the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Physician Faculty Scholars Program 2009 National Meeting in San Diego California, December 7-10, 2009. Dr. Sudore is a Physician Faculty Scholar (Class of 2012) and gave a slide presentation about enhancing advance care planning in diverse elders with limited literacy.  The goal of her work is to better enable patients to engage in the advance care planning process and to make appropriate medical decisions at the end of life.  Dr. Walter was a Physician Faculty Scholar (Class of 2009) and was invited to attend the meeting to moderate a research poster session and provide mentorship.
 
Angela Hsu, MD (Clinical Geriatrics Fellow) is the first author in the American Journal of Public Health Article
Angela Hsu, MD (Clinical Geriatrics Fellow) is the first author on the article in the American Journal of Public Health titled, Changes in Postmenopausal Hormone Replacement Therapy Use Among Women With High Cardiovascular Risk. In this Article, Dr. Hsu presents intriguing findings that suggest many women may have received HRT for prevention of cardiovascular disease, and that racial and economic disparities in healthcare that may have helped minority women and those of low socioeconomic status avoid receiving this potentially harmful therapy.

Leslie Kernisan, MD, MPH
MED-GERIATRICS
Clinical Instructor
PO Box 170376

drkernisan@geriatricsforcaregivers.net


Overview

Dr. Leslie Kernisan is a Clinical Instructor in the Division of Geriatrics, where as a volunteer clinical faculty member, she regularly teaches core clinical geriatric skills to UCSF students.

A graduate of Princeton University, Leslie completed both her residency in Internal Medicine and fellowship in Geriatrics at UCSF.

Keen to improve the health care system for elders and their caregivers, Leslie additionally pursued two year VA Quality Scholar fellowship at UCSF, studying epidemiology, biostatistics, health systems, and quality improvement. She then completed a Masters in Public Health at Berkeley, and studied the intersection between caregiving and the Internet, while collaborating with Caring.com, a website providing information and support to caregivers. Her research on health care quality was published in the Journal of the American Medical Association in 2009; another paper on caregiver information-seeking was published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research in 2010.


Clinical

From 2010-2012 Leslie practiced primary care geriatrics at the Over 60 Health Center in Berkeley, where she was instrumental in planning a transition to electronic health records. During her last nine months there, she also served as the clinics medical director, overseeing clinical care, overhauling the housecalls program, and working on quality improvement.  

Leslie now sees Bay Area patients at home through her own solo housecalls and geriatric consultation practice. She also blogs about geriatrics and technology at GeriTech.org, and is a Senior Medical Editor at Caring.com.

Sandra Moody, MD
Associate Professor of Medicine
sandra.moody@ucsf.edu




Sandra Y. Moody, MD, BSN, AGSF is an Associate Professor of Medicine in the Division of Geriatrics at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) and Veterans Affairs Medical Center (SFVAMC) and Professor-in-Residence at Kameda Medical Center in Kamogawa City, Chiba, Japan.

Dr. Moody received her MD from the Ohio State University College of Medicine in 1991. She completed a residency in Internal Medicine and fellowships in the Robert Wood Johnson Clinical Scholars Program and Geriatrics Medicine at Yale University School of Medicine. Dr. Moody joined the faculty at UCSF in August 2001. She has developed a national reputation in diversity and health disparities.

Dr. Moody was founder of the Division of Geriatrics Hospice and Palliative Care Service (2001-2004), which is now one of the leading programs in Veterans Affairs nationally. Her work was recognized by a nomination for the Marshall Goodwin-Beck Interdisciplinary Award for Excellence in Clinical Delivery (2005), an award that recognizes an individual practitioner demonstrating excellence in hands on direct geriatric patient care. She is currently living in Japan teaching at the Kameda Medical Center, which is one of the top residency-training programs in Japan. She participates in activities in Japan advancing the care of older adults.

CLINICAL AND RESEARCH ACTIVITIES
Dr. Moody is passionate about leading and developing clinical programs. In addition to building the hospice and palliative care program, she was the Medical Director of the Home Based Primary Care program at SFVAMC (2007-2011) where she led a large interdisciplinary team encompassing nursing, psychiatry/psychology, pharmacy, social work, and dietary, advancing the care of homebound, frail elderly veterans. She currently attends on the SFVAMC/UCSF Division of Geriatrics Hospice and Palliative Care Service annually where she not only teaches UCSF trainees, but also invited Japanese medical residents from Kameda Medical Center.

Dr. Moody's teaching activities involve teaching fellows, residents, and students at both UCSF/SFVAMC and Kameda Medical Center. She has been recognized with teaching awards for her teaching efforts. She has completed the prestigious California Health Care Foundation Healthcare Leadership Program as a fellow in September 2011. Dr. Moody received research training in the Robert Wood Johnson Clinical Scholars Program at Yale University School of Medicine and has collaborated on research projects focusing on health disparities among racial and ethnic groups. Through her research, she strives to address the issue of inequality through topics pertaining to perceived racism and lifecourse socioeconomic status.

ACADEMIC FOCUS
Dr. Moodys academic focus is to improve the care of diverse frail elderly patients with multiple chronic and life-threatening conditions through teaching and program development. She has developed clinical programs in the arena of hospice and palliative care as well as home-based care. Her interests have expanded to include an international focus. Currently living and teaching in Japan at one of the top residency training programs, she teaches clinical reasoning and western approaches to clinical medicine. She has developed core curriculum in geriatrics to address the gap in geriatrics education in Japan. She gives invited lectures in both end-of-life care and geriatrics.

SELECTED PRESENTATIONS

  • Plenary speaker, Geriatrics Medical Education: Implications for Japan, 54th Annual Meeting of Japan Geriatrics Society [theme: Geriatric Medicine in Super-aged Society], Tokyo, Japan, 2012
  • Lecturer, Demonstration of a Brief Geriatric Assessment, Kameda Medical Center, Chiba, Japan, 2012
  • Lecturer, Care of the Hospitalized Elderly, Kameda Medical Center, Chiba, Japan, 2011

HONORS AND AWARDS

  • 2003 Teacher of the Year, Division of Geriatrics, UCSF
  • 2005 Nominee, Marshall Goodwin-Beck Interdisciplinary Award for Excellence in Clinical Delivery [recognizes an individual practitioner in any health care setting who has demonstrated excellence in hands on direct geriatric patient care], SFVAMC/Division of Geriatrics
  • 2005 Excellence in Direct Teaching, Haile T. Debas Academy of Medical Educators, UCSF
  • 2006 Certificate of Appreciation, In recognition of valuable contributions as a volunteer to Society of General Internal Medicine, Annual Meeting Program Committee, Co-Chair, Clinical Vignettes Review and Selection. SGIM 26th Annual Meeting.
  • 2007 Selected for the VISN 21 Physician Leadership Academy, Department of Veterans Affairs

  • 2009 Champion of Diversity Award, Honors Champions of Diversity, UCSF, June
  • 2011 Certificate of Completion, CHCF Health Care Leadership Program, The California HealthCare Foundation and The Center for the Health Professions, University of California, San Francisco
  • 2012 Fellow, American Geriatrics Society, Seattle, Washington, May

The Acute Care for Elders (ACE) Unit at the Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital was started in February, 2007 and cares for over 400 older patients each year. It is the first ACE unit in California. The mission of the ACE Unit is to provide the best inpatient care for hospitalized older adults with a focus on maintaining and improving physical and cognitive function. The ACE unit is major site of Geriatrics teaching at UCSF for medical students, interns and residents, and Geriatrics fellows.

Hospitalization is a risky period for older adults. Many of us are aware of older relatives or friends who are not quite the same after hospitalization. Patients may be weaker or have difficulty managing their affairs afterwards. Some of this decline can be avoided through a patient-centered, interdisciplinary, approach using best evidence to guide care.

The ACE unit accomplishes this through:

  • Interdisciplinary care in a prepared environment.
  • Careful medication review to eliminate unnecessary medications.
  • Deployment of non-medication interventions such as exercise, socialization, and focus on sleep hygiene.
  • Early planning for discharge to home.

Edgar Pierluissi, MD

Each morning, patients are seen by healthcare professionals including a physician, a nurse, an occupational therapist, a pharmacist, and a social worker. This team then meets to discuss the plan of care bringing their specific area of expertise to bear for each patient. The team continues to evaluate each patients progress until hospital discharge.

The ACE unit exports its knowledge and expertise to other units throughout the hospital through education sessions.

Bridges provides home-based palliative consultations for UCSF adult patients of all ages living in San Francisco.

UC Care at Homes Bridges program aims to help our UCSF patients living with serious illness receive the best care possible. Bridges offers home-visits by physicians, nurse practitioners, social workers, and chaplains who specialize in symptom management, communication, and safe transitions from hospital to home. Our team works closely with a patients primary and specialty care providers, as well as home health and hospice agencies.

Bridges can help UCSF patients and families:

  • Create a clear and effective plan for managing symptoms at home
  • Understand their illness and what to expect in the future
  • Ensure a safe and comfortable transition from hospital to home
  • Make important medical decisions based on the patients hopes and values
  • Coordinate effectively with medical providers
  • Connect to medical and social support resources

Patients are referred to Bridges by their UCSF physician in the hospital or clinic. To qualify for Bridges patients must: be over 18 years old, live in San Francisco, have a serious and/or chronic progressive illness, have difficulty leaving the home for activities other than medical appointments, and have UCSF primary care or specialist provider they see regularly.

To find out more about the program or refer a patient, please call the program at (415) 514-3577.

This program is UCSFs vision for how patient centered care should be delivered to frail older adults nationwide-safely and soundly in the context of a persons home. We provide transitional care after hospitalization, as well as primary care and end-of-life care at home.UCSF Care at Home includes three programs:

  1. UCSF Housecalls enrolls homebound older persons through doctor referrals or through direct inquiry by calling (415) 514-3577.
  2. UCSF Home-Based Transitional Care provides short-term transitional care for older people with chronic conditions, such as heart failure, recently discharged from the UCSF Medical Center.
  3. Home-Based Palliative Care provides intensive symptom management services at home for people with serious or terminal illness.

The UCSF Care Support Service provides hospital transition support and ongoing intensive care management for medically
complex adult patients who have UCSF primary care providers at the Division of General Internal Medicine Clinic
(DGIM), Family Medicine Center at Lakeshore or UCSF Center for Geriatric Care.

Our role is to complement primary care by partnering with the primary care providers to support our most medically complex patients. Our partnership will provide comprehensive patient-centered support across the spectrum of care to bring patients to their highest level of wellness possible.

Our Team

The Care Support teams embedded in the primary care clinics are:

Family Medicine Center at Lakeshore & UCSF Center for Geriatric Care
Erika Tunick, MSW and Robin Andersen, NP

Division of General Internal Medicine (DGIM)
Lisa Sapiro, LCSW and Anne Thibault, NP

Goals

  • Improving the functional status and quality of life of our patients
  • Promoting the appropriate utilization of medical resources
  • Supporting the primary care providers and improving provider satisfaction

Key Components of Care Support

  • A comprehensive initial in-home assessment by the nurse practitioner and social worker.
  • Weekly team case conference with an interdisciplinary team (geriatrician, psychologist, pharmacist, social workers, nurse practitioner) for care planning.
  • Primary care physician reviews and provides input on the careplan to the Nurse Practitioner/Social Worker
  • A follow-up home or clinic visit to review and then initiate the care plan with the patient and family.
  • Ongoing intensive care management based on the care plan including medication reconciliation, care coordination, social support, linkages to community resources, education on self-management skills including self-monitoring for seeking medical attention. Follow-up will take place in the clinic, by telephone or in the home as needed.

Care Support Focus

  • Transitions of care
  • Chronic care & medication self management
  • Substance abuse
  • Chronic pain
  • Mental Health issues
  • Mobility/Falls
  • Dementia/Cognitive Status
  • Geriatric conditions
  • Nutrition/Weight issues
  • Caregiver support
  • Social Service coordination
  • Advanced care planning


    Juliet Pult
    Program Coordinator

Formerly known as the Lakeside Senior Medical Center, the UCSF Center for Geriatric Care offers patients personalized care from doctors who specialize in caring for older adults.

The practice cares for patients 70 years of age or older. Clinical services include full-time medical and nursing providers. Podiatry, social work and laboratory services are provided on site. Relocated to a brand new space on the ground level of the Institute on Aging campus in July 2013, the new clinic site offers easy curb side drop off, wheel chair accessibility and numerous older adult education, support groups and other resources on site. The UCSF Center for Geriatric Care collaborates with UC Hastings College of the Law to provide a Medical-Legal Partnership for Seniors, one of a few such practices nationwide which provides health-related legal aide to older adults. The UCSF Center for Geriatric Care also trains future health care providers how to care for older adults.
