Abstract^

Objective: To examine the impact of illness on the families of seriously ill adults and to determine the correlates of adverse economic impact.

Design: Data were collected during the Study to Understand Prognoses and Preferences for Outcomes and Risks of Treatment (SUPPORT), a prospective cohort study of outcomes, preferences, and decision making in seriously ill hospitalized adults and their families.

Setting: Five tertiary care hospitals in the United States.

Participants: The 2661 seriously ill patients in nine diagnostic categories who survived their index hospitalization and were discharged home were eligible for this analysis. Surrogate and/or patient interviews about the impact of illness on the family were obtained for 2129 (80%) of these patients (mean age, 62 years; 43% women; 6-month survival, 75%).

Outcome Measures: Surrogates and patients were surveyed to determine the frequency of adverse caregiving and economic burdens. Multivariable analyses were performed to determine correlates of loss of family savings.

Results: One third (34%) of patients required considerable caregiving assistance from a family member. In 20% of cases, a family member had to quit work or make another major life change to provide care for the patient. Loss of most or all of the family savings was reported by 31% of families, whereas 29% reported loss of the major source of income. Patient factors independently associated with loss of the family's savings on multivariable analysis included poor functional status (odds ratio (OR), 1.40; 95% confidence interval (CI), 1.10 to 1.78 for patients needing assistance with three or more activities of daily living), lower family income (OR, 1.74; 95% CI, 1.37 to 2.21 for those with annual incomes below $25 000), and young age (OR, 2.85; 95% CI, 2.13 to 3.82 for those younger than 45 years compared with those 65 years or older).

Conclusions: Many families of seriously ill patients experience severe caregiving and financial burdens. Families of younger, poorer, and more functionally dependent patients are most likely to report loss of most or all of the family's savings.

(JAMA. 1994;272:1839-1844)


Major illnesses can have a substantial impact on patients' and their families' lifestyles and finances. For example, among a group of more than 400 cancer patients, more than 90% were dependent on another person for assistance with personal care, shopping, or transportation [1]. Their caregivers reported substantial burdens, including the use of savings and loans to subsidize their efforts. Unfortunately, the burden of illness affects many families. Of patients attending a family practice clinic, 20% reported they were helping to care for a functionally impaired relative [2]. Anecdotal experience and a limited amount of research suggest that economic and psychosocial burdens imposed by severe illness can be devastating to patients' families.

To provide more information on this topic, we measured the frequency of caregiving and financial burdens caused by serious illness on the families of patients surviving hospitalization. We also examined whether demographic and clinical factors such as race, income, marital status, and functional dependency were correlated with adverse economic impact.

METHODS^
Description of SUPPORT Cohort^
The Study to Understand Prognoses and Preferences for Outcomes and Risks of Treatment (SUPPORT) study design is described in detail elsewhere [3]. Briefly, the SUPPORT Project is a multicenter prospective study of preferences, outcomes, and decision making in seriously ill hospitalized adults and their families. The observational phase of the SUPPORT Project enrolled patients at least 18 years of age presenting to any of five participating clinical sites (Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, Mass; Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC; St Joseph's Hospital, Marshfield, Wis; MetroHealth Medical Center, Cleveland, Ohio; or UCLA Medical Center, Los Angeles, Calif) between June 12, 1989, and June 11, 1991, who met prespecified criteria for one of nine diagnoses (acute respiratory failure, severe congestive heart failure, severe cirrhosis, nontraumatic coma, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, metastatic lung cancer, metastatic colon cancer, and multiple organ system failure with sepsis or malignancy), each associated with an expected 6-month mortality rate between 30% and 70%. Surrogates of patients were identified by asking the patients whom they would want to make decisions in their place if they were unable to do so. The study was approved by the institutional review boards at all participating sites. A total of 4301 patients met criteria for entry into SUPPORT. We limited our analysis to the 2661 patients who survived the index hospitalization and were discharged home. This analytic sample had a lower severity of illness and better prognosis than the overall SUPPORT cohort. For example, 6-month survival for the analytic sample was 73% compared with 52% for the entire SUPPORT cohort.

Data Collection^
Data were collected by trained chart abstractors and interviewers. Clinical information such as disease category, number of comorbidities, and the Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation III (APACHE III) score [4] was obtained by chart review during the index admission. Data on number of comorbid illnesses were abstracted using a system developed for APACHE II [5]. To measure the patient's functional status 2 weeks prior to hospitalization, a revised version of the Katz Activity of Daily Living Scale was administered to patients and surrogates during the index hospitalization [6]. Functional status was determined by the patient's responses to the survey (n=1273), unless the patient was unable to be interviewed, in which case the surrogate's responses were used (n=597). Patients were classified as functionally dependent if they were dependent on others for three or more activities of daily living. This represents the quintile of the cohort with the greatest functional dependency. Demographic information included age, race, gender, and marital status. The patient's family income for the calendar year prior to the hospitalization was obtained by interviewing the patient or surrogate during the index admission. Information as to whether the patient, surrogate, or other family member was the primary wage earner was not obtained. Information about postdischarge readmission rates was obtained from patient and surrogate interviews. Hospital billing information was obtained from each site. Insurance status at the time of admission was classified as none, private, Medicaid, Medicare only, or Medicare with private or Medicaid insurance.

Patients and their surrogates were interviewed about the impact of the patient's illness on family members. The family impact interview, which included questions about both the financial impact of the illness and the caregiving burden for family members, was administered to patients and surrogates at 2 and 6 months following hospital discharge Table 1. Surrogates of patients who survived less than 6 months were also interviewed after the patient's death.


Table 1. Family Impact Questions and Derivation of Response Categories
Because we were most concerned about the impact of the illness as perceived by the family, we used the responses of the surrogate to the family impact questions as the primary response. Because we were interested in identifying families who had suffered adverse impacts at any time during the illness, we considered a family to have experienced an adverse impact for a particular item if it was reported on any surrogate interview. If no surrogate interview was available, we used the patient's family impact interview.

Statistical Analysis^
Patients in the analytic sample were characterized in terms of age, gender, race, marital status, income, functional dependency, and hospital charges. Patient and surrogate responses to the family impact items were compared using the kappa statistic [7](pp456-458). Directionality of disagreement was measured using McNemar's test for paired data [7](pp344-346). The data presented on patient-surrogate comparisons combine data from the 2- and 6-month postdischarge interviews when a response was available from both the patient and the surrogate. The kappa statistics that consider the 2- and 6-month interviews separately are similar and therefore are not reported. To assess for adverse economic impact, we compared patients whose families reported loss of most or all of their savings with those who did not. Independent variables included patient demographics (age, race, gender, marital status, and family income), functional dependency, and hospital charges. Age was divided by decades with 65 years chosen as the critical cut point because it is the age at which most US citizens become eligible for Medicare and Social Security. Hospital charges were divided into quartiles. The significance of the possible independent predictors was assessed by performing chi squared (chi2) tests or chi squared (chi2) tests for trend.

A logistic regression model was developed to identify correlates of loss of family savings [8] after controlling for the patient's diagnostic category (entered as dummy variables for each of the nine SUPPORT diagnostic categories), APACHE III score, number of comorbidities, and the length of time the patient survived (entered as dummy variables for survival between 2 and 6 months and survival for more than 6 months, reflecting the time points of the follow-up interviews). All other variables that had univariable associations at P<.20 were entered into the multivariable model and retained if they attained a significance level of P<.05. Because income, functional status, and hospital charge data were often missing (486, 254, and 124 patients, respectively), patients with missing income, functional status, and hospital charge data had this information imputed for the regression model using an algorithm designed for SUPPORT based on other demographic and clinical variables. Income was imputed by constructing a regression tree that contained patient ZIP code, insurance status, site of enrollment, and years of education. For functional status, the algorithm was based on an ordinal logistic regression model containing terms for patient diagnosis, age, Glasgow Coma Score, a modified version of the APACHE III score, comorbidities, and geographic site of enrollment. Hospital charges were imputed based on patients' average therapeutic intensity score [9] and their length of stay. The regression analysis yielded similar results with or without the imputed data; the odds ratios for each of the significant variables changed no more than 15%. Therefore, the regression results that are presented use imputed data. Additionally, the correlates of loss of savings were similar when only the month 2 or month 6 loss of savings outcome was considered. The analyses presented consider the correlates of those who reported loss of savings at any time point.

After the initial prespecified analyses were performed, several additional logistic regression analyses were performed to answer questions raised by our initial findings. First, to determine whether age was a correlate of markers of adverse economic impact other than loss of savings, logistic regression analyses were performed to determine whether age was also an independent correlate of loss of income and change in family plans because of the costs of illness. Second, to determine whether health insurance status modified the correlates of loss of savings, the loss of savings regression analysis was repeated with the addition of variables for type of insurance. Separate analyses were performed for patients aged 65 years and older and those younger than 65 years because of the nearly complete colinearity between older age and the presence of Medicare insurance.

RESULTS^
Characteristics of Patients^
Of the 2661 patients eligible for inclusion in this analysis, family impact interviews were obtained for 2129 (80%). For 1950 (92%) of these patients the family impact interview was obtained from the surrogate. For the remaining 8% without surrogate interviews, the patient's interview was used. The relationships of the interviewed surrogates to the patients were as follows: spouse, 48%; child, 29%; parent, 7%; sibling, 8%; and other, 8%. Seventy-one percent (1333) of the interviewed surrogates for whom gender was recorded were women. (Surrogate gender was not recorded for 4% of interviewed surrogates.) The mean age of the patients studied was 61.6 years, and 43% were women Table 2. Patients without family impact interviews from either the patient or the surrogate were more likely than those with such interviews to be married (60% vs 55%, P<.05), had slightly higher APACHE III scores (28.6 vs 26.7, P=.002), and were less likely to survive 6 months (65% vs 75%, P<.001), but were similar in terms of the other variables listed in Table 2.


Table 2. Characteristics of Patients With Family Impact Interviews (n=2129)
Results of Family Impact Survey^
One third (34%) of the patients required considerable caregiving assistance from a family member Table 3. Severe caregiving burdens were reported by many families, including the need to make major life changes to care for the patient and an inability to function normally because of the stress of the illness. A large number of families reported losing most of their savings (31%) or their major source of income (29%). The costs of illness required 17% of families to change personal plans. Patients whose families experienced one adverse impact often had other adverse impacts as well. For example, loss of family savings was more likely to be reported if an impact was reported for any of the other family impact items (P<.001 by chi squared (chi2) for all comparisons). At least one major adverse impact (defined as any impact except requiring caregiving assistance) was experienced by more than half (55%) of the families.


Table 3. Responses to Family Impact Survey
Agreement Between Patients and Surrogates^
The kappa statistic comparing patient and surrogate responses to the family impact interview ranged from 0.19 for the item about whether someone else in the family became ill or unable to function normally to 0.54 for the item asking whether the main source of income was lost Table 4. For the loss of family savings item, the kappa statistic was 0.43. Among disagreeing patient-surrogate pairs, the surrogate was more likely to report that someone in the family quit work or made a major life change to care for the patient or that someone in the family became ill because of the stress of the illness (McNemar P<.05). The patient was more likely to report loss of family income (McNemar P<.05). For items regarding loss of savings and whether a change in family plans occurred because of the costs of illness, patients and surrogates were equally likely to report an impact (McNemar P>.05).


Table 4. Comparison of Patient and Surrogate Responses to Family Impact Survey
Univariable Correlates of Loss of Family Savings^
Patients whose families were more likely to lose all or most of the family savings were younger (P<.001) and more often nonwhite (P<.05), had lower incomes (P<.001), and had worse functional status (P<.01) than patients not reporting loss of savings Table 5. The effect of age on loss of family savings increased continuously through the age of 65 years, with increasing age offering increasing protection. However, the influence of age plateaued after 65 years. Marital status, patient or surrogate gender, survival time, hospitalization costs, and rates of rehospitalization were not associated with loss of family savings.


Table 5. Factors Associated With Loss of Family Savings on Univariable Analysis
Multivariable Analyses^
When we adjusted for disease severity and diagnosis, variables associated with loss of family savings by logistic regression analysis were younger age, lower income, and poor functional status Table 6. Race and diagnosis were not correlated with loss of savings.


Table 6. Multivariable Correlates of Loss of Savings
In secondary multivariable analyses, younger patient age was also independently correlated with loss of the major income source for the family (odds ratio, 5.21; 95% confidence interval, 3.71 to 7.32 for patients younger than 45 years compared with those older than 65 years) and with a change in family plans because of the costs of illness (odds ratio, 1.99; 95% confidence interval, 1.36 to 2.91 for patients younger than 45 years compared with those older than 65 years). To evaluate the effect of insurance coverage at the time of hospitalization on loss of savings, we performed separate multivariable analyses in patients older and younger than 65 years, because patients aged 65 years and older uniformly had Medicare insurance. In patients younger than 65 years, younger age and lower income remained independent correlates of loss of savings. Using patients with private insurance as the reference group, we determined that the type of insurance coverage, or lack thereof, was not correlated independently with loss of savings. In patients older than 65 years, poor functional status and low income remained independent correlates of loss of savings. Age beyond 65 years was not correlated with loss of savings; the presence or absence of supplemental Medicaid or private insurance was not an independent correlate of loss of savings.

COMMENT^
We found that families of seriously ill patients experienced severe caregiving and financial burdens. More than half of the families reported at least one severe caregiving or financial burden, and nearly one third reported losing most or all of the family savings. Many families had to make changes in other family plans such as moving to a less expensive home, delaying education, or putting off medical care for others. Clearly, serious medical illnesses are devastating not only to patients but also to their families.

These results are consistent with those of other studies that demonstrate severe burdens on families and caregivers of the seriously ill. In a study by Siegel et al [1] of oncology patients, loss of savings was reported by a similar proportion of patients. Among spouses of patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting, nearly one third reported severe anxiety and nearly half reported their financial situation to be highly inadequate [10]. Severe financial burdens have also been reported by the families of pediatric patients with cancer [11].

Other investigators have examined the impact of a patient's illness on the health of family members. For example, increased utilization of medical services among the families of the seriously ill has been reported [12]. Spouses of patients with Alzheimer's disease reported poorer mental and physical health than the general population [13]. The results we report herein extend previous work on the burdens experienced by family members to large numbers of seriously ill patients with multiple diagnoses at geographically diverse medical centers throughout the United States.

Although our results document substantial burdens to the family members of seriously ill patients, they do not explain the mechanism of these burdens. These burdens occurred even though 96% of the patients had hospitalization insurance. Further, inpatient hospital charges and rehospitalization were not independently associated with loss of savings, suggesting that the costs associated with hospitalization may not be the most important mediators of family financial burden. While hospital costs are of critical importance to third-party payers and policymakers, it is possible that home care costs and disability costs may be more relevant to patients and their families. The National Medical Expenditure Survey suggested that a substantial proportion of home care expenses is not reimbursed by either private or public insurance [14]. Home care service use was reported for 40% of the patients in our cohort (data not shown). However, because we have no information about the source of payment for these services in our cohort, our data cannot specifically answer how the use of and need for home care services influenced family impact. Our results highlight the need for future research efforts to examine the mechanism of these burdens and to collect detailed data about the costs of illness to patients and their families, including the unreimbursed costs of home care and measures of income loss, both to the patient and to the caregiver.

While loss of savings was reported by a substantial number of families in all demographic groups, this burden was greatest for families of patients who had the lowest incomes, who had severe functional dependency, and who were younger. The relationship between low income and loss of savings is not surprising and probably results from those with less income having less savings. Likewise, it is not surprising that families of more functionally dependent patients were more likely to lose their savings, because these families most likely had greater expenses related to the need for greater caregiving assistance.

Although the data from this study do not allow us to conclude with certainty why families of younger patients experience economic burdens with a much greater frequency than families of older patients, there are several possible explanations. First, older patients have had more time to accrue savings than younger patients and therefore might have had a higher baseline level of savings. Second, older patients are, in general, eligible for more social support services than younger patients. Third, guaranteed income sources separate from employment, such as Social Security and pensions, become available as one ages. These alternative income sources would provide older patients with income that would not be eliminated by illness. Finally, the nearly uniform availability of Medicare insurance to patients aged 65 years or older may explain part of the protective effect of age. However, this hypothesis needs to be explored in future research comparing the reimbursed and unreimbursed expenses of patients with and without Medicare insurance. While other data from SUPPORT suggest that younger patients use more hospital resources than older patients even when illness severity is controlled for [15], adjusting for hospital resource use in our regression model did not affect the relationship between loss of savings and age. However, because we did not measure outpatient resource use, we cannot exclude the possibility that more intensive use of outpatient resources contributed to the loss of savings in younger patients.

While our results apply only to patients with severe, life-threatening illness, a previous survey of ambulatory patients without life-threatening illnesses also showed a strong tendency for younger patients to report financial burdens at a much greater rate [16]. Younger patient age was also an independent predictor of families' experiencing the other financial burdens in our survey, such as loss of income and change in family plans because of the costs of illness. Although legislative attempts to enact catastrophic health coverage have previously focused on the elderly, our finding that families of younger patients are much more likely to experience financial burdens suggests that younger patients' need for catastrophic coverage may be just as great as that of elderly patients. Further, the concept of catastrophic coverage needs to be expanded to consider home care and disability costs as well.

While both surrogates and patients reported a high level of caregiving burden and economic distress, there was only fair to moderate pairwise agreement between patients and surrogates about whether the family had been affected in a particular area. It is to be expected that patients and surrogates would view these burdens from different perspectives. Furthermore, this disagreement was not surprising in light of previous findings that surrogates and patients often give contradictory answers when asked about functional dependency and resuscitation preferences [17,18]. Although we cannot be certain, the surrogate may be more accurate than the patient in reporting family burdens, because the surrogate is often the person most directly experiencing this burden.

Several limitations of our analysis should be noted. First, our family impact items were subjective and may have been interpreted differently by family members of different ages or socioeconomic backgrounds. Affirmative responses may indicate different levels of distress for different families. Indeed, previous research demonstrates differences in the perceptions of caregiving burden across different racial backgrounds and family structures [19,20]. For example, even though we observed no gender differences on the loss of savings item, this does not exclude the possibility of an actual gender effect if either men or women were to perceive the same amount of savings loss differently. Because we did not collect data on prior savings, we were unable to quantify the monetary loss for families in our study. Also, while we assumed that loss of most or all of one's savings, no matter how large or small the amount, would reflect a severe level of distress from the family's perspective, we did not collect information on actual expenses. For example, we do not know whether the savings were being consumed by loss of income, by provision of health services that were not reimbursable, or by copayments. We also do not know to what extent lost income may have been made up in some cases by disability insurance. In addition, these data do not permit us to draw conclusions about the extent to which health insurance might protect families from financial burden. The number of uninsured patients was small, and we do not know whether the patients' insurance status changed during the course of their illness. Also, we did not explicitly attempt to interview caregivers. However, because 92% of the surrogates interviewed were first-degree relatives of the patients, it is reasonable to assume that they were familiar with the family's situation even if they were not directly involved in caregiving. Finally, while the patients in SUPPORT were representative of a large number of hospitalized patients with catastrophic illnesses, our findings should not be generalized to outpatients or those with chronic illnesses that are not life-threatening. Indeed, a prior study of outpatients with less severe illness found a somewhat lower (12%) incidence of financial burdens [16].

Our results have a number of additional implications for health policy and future research. The prevalence of family burden suggests that the family impact of illness should be considered in planning health system reform and should be one of the outcomes used to measure the effectiveness of reform. The impact of serious illness on families and caregivers not only is an important outcome for patients, but to a certain degree can be viewed as a measure of functioning for the nation's health care system. As a greater proportion of the care of the seriously ill occurs at home, it will be necessary to study the burdens home care places on the family. Strategies such as respite care should be tested to determine to what extent they lessen burdens. Special emphasis should be placed on protecting the savings of younger, poorer, and more functionally dependent patients as they become ill. In addition to evaluating the effectiveness of interventions to lessen the burden on families, future research should be designed to improve our understanding of how serious illness places burdens on the family and the community.

We would like to express our gratitude to Joel Weissman, PhD, C. This program is UCSFs vision for how patient centered care should be delivered to frail older adults nationwide-safely and soundly in the context of a persons home. We provide transitional care after hospitalization, as well as primary care and end-of-life care at home.UCSF Care at Home includes three programs:

  1. UCSF Housecalls enrolls homebound older persons through doctor referrals or through direct inquiry by calling (415) 514-3577.
  2. UCSF Home-Based Transitional Care provides short-term transitional care for older people with chronic conditions, such as heart failure, recently discharged from the UCSF Medical Center.
  3. Home-Based Palliative Care provides intensive symptom management services at home for people with serious or terminal illness.

Private philanthropy is critical to the transformation of geriatrics.  The waiting lists are long for all UCSF geriatric clinical programs.  The need is great and far outstrips our resources to recruit and support talented trainees and faculty, or to expand geriatric education and research programs.

All gifts are tax deductible in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code.

Recruit and Support Talented Trainees and Faculty

  • Faculty Endowments provide a permanent financial commitment for faculty who are passionate about geriatrics.  These funds allow them to focus their full energy and talents on building their research, teaching and clinical programs.
  • Training Support enables us to attract the best and brightest trainees to careers in geriatrics.  These funds will allow us to expand geriatric training to more students, residents, fellows and other health professionals.

  • Research and Education Support creates start-up funds for investing in the development of novel research and education programs to meet the growing needs of older adults in the Bay Area and beyond.

Heart failure program coordinators Maureen Carroll, RN, CHFN (center), and Eileen Brinker, RN, MSN, with UCSF Medical Center patient Alethea Travis. Carroll and Brinker are part of a new team effort to reduce preventable readmissions among heart failure patients.



Improved care of elderly patients with heart failure has led to shorter hospital stays and lower rates of death while in the hospital. Unfortunately, after leaving the hospital, many of these patients are at risk of being admitted to a nursing home, are frequently re-admitted to the hospital, or die in the month following hospital discharge. Working with a multidisciplinary team, UCSF Medical Center has been able to care for more patients in their homes, prevent hospital readmissions and provide palliative care for those with late-stage heart failure.

Heart failure affects about 5 million Americans, and is the leading cause of 30-day hospital readmissions among older patients. It is a chronic, progressive disease in which the heart is unable to pump enough blood to the rest of the body, causing fatigue, shortness of breath and swelling in the feet and legs. Patients often take multiple medications to manage their illness, must restrict their salt intake, and need to weigh themselves daily to detect whether they are retaining excess fluid, which can back up into their lungs. Yet despite the complexity of the disease, some studies have estimated that up to half of heart failure readmissions are potentially preventable.

In 2006, 23 percent of heart failure patients age 65 and older were readmitted to UCSF Medical Center within a month of discharge, whereas by 2011, only 12 percent were readmitted. (The national average is 25 percent.) The rate of heart failure patients readmitted to the hospital within 90 days also dropped, from 45 percent in 2006 to 27 percent in 2011 a 40 percent reduction.

Each hospital readmission has a story, and we try to find out what it is, says Eileen Brinker, RN, MSN, program coordinator for a recently established heart failure readmission initiative at UCSF. Were they able to get their medications? Are they unable to get to appointments because they cant get down the stairs? Is the patients caregiver burned out?

Brinker and her fellow program coordinator, Maureen Carroll, RN, CHFN, are at the center of UCSFs successful efforts to provide better care to older heart failure patients. By cultivating excellent communication, patient education, team approaches to care and careful attention to transitions between hospital and home, the program has reduced 30-day readmissions for heart failure patients 65 and older by nearly half compared to five years ago.

In 2006, 23 percent of heart failure patients age 65 and older were readmitted to UCSF Medical Center within a month of discharge, whereas by 2011, only 12 percent were readmitted. (The national average is 25 percent.) The rate of heart failure patients readmitted to the hospital within 90 days also dropped, from 45 percent in 2006 to 27 percent in 2011 a 40 percent reduction.

Our team takes ownership of the patient, like theyre part of our family. Our goals are to reduce hospitalization, help patients feel better and do more to slow progression of their disease, and improve longevity.

Teresa De Marco, MD, director of the Heart Failure and Pulmonary Hypertension Program

Building a Team

Creating teams that look at the whole patient is part of becoming accountable for the continuum of care, says Teresa De Marco, MD, director of the Heart Failure Program at UCSF, and a physician champion of the heart failure readmission reduction initiative. Our team takes ownership of the patient, like theyre part of our family. We want to make sure they do well, not just when they are in the hospital, but after they are discharged. Our goals are to reduce hospitalization, help patients feel better and do more to slow progression of their disease, and improve longevity.

The heart failure readmission reduction project was established in 2008, with funding from the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. This grant enabled UCSF Medical Center to hire Brinker and Carroll both experienced cardiac floor nurses to lead the initiative. They began by building a multidisciplinary team, including physicians, nurses, case managers, social workers, dieticians, chaplains and palliative care specialists. We want to make sure that everyone is involved who should be, says Brinker. Because we know the players so well, we can pull everyone in when it is appropriate.

This team identified the key issues in the care of heart failure patients and implemented processes to improve their care. Brinker and Carroll developed an e-mail system to notify inpatient and outpatient providers and other team members when heart failure patients are readmitted. They ensured that patients discharged from the hospital would receive a follow-up appointment with their primary care physician, or the outpatient heart failure clinic. We realized that sometimes the outpatient clinics didnt know when their patients were hospitalized, even though they are just across the street, says Brinker.

They updated patient education materials, translated them into four languages and established better methods for teaching patients and their families about the disease and its management. Instead of cramming education into a hurried monologue on the day of discharge, Brinker and Carroll arrange to discuss different topics with patients each day they are hospitalized and build relationships in the process. We have the privilege of having time to spend at the bedside with patients and their families, says Carroll. Our mantra is, Listen before we teach. Just taking the time to get to know the patient establishes a trust. They trained team members in the teach-back method, asking patients to explain key concepts in their own words, which demonstrates comprehension and indicates if any points need to be explained another way.

They also call to check on patients within one week of discharge, again by day 14, and may make several more calls, depending on a patients needs. They dont think to tell us, but because we are asking, we find out things like they havent gotten their meds for three days, says Carroll. Its a great way to troubleshoot.

Receiving Care at Home

The most frail older heart failure patients are referred to GeriTraCCC, which stands for Geriatric Transitions, Consultation, and Comprehensive Care. The UCSF program was established in 2010 with support from the S.D. Bechtel, Jr. Foundation. Our readmissions had gone down to a certain level during the first year of the heart failure program, but incorporating GeriTraCCC brought our readmission rate down quite a bit more, says Carroll.

After a home visit, geriatrician Helen Kao, MD (right), and home health care nurse Laura Franklin discuss next steps.

There is a subset of patients who need a higher level of follow-up to maintain their stability, says Helen Kao, MD, GeriTraCCCs medical director. Kao or a colleague makes a housecall to these patients within 48 hours of discharge, a critical transition period. They ensure that patients are taking the right amount of each medication, adjust doses as needed, and assess patients functional and cognitive abilities and their risk of falling. GeriTraCCC is not meant to replace the primary care physician or cardiologist, but rather to extend their reach, says Kao.

GeriTraCCCs involvement might range from a few housecalls, to staying involved for months and enlisting a whole team, including nurses and physical therapists who can visit patients in their homes. We can coordinate our schedules so somebody has an eye on that patient almost every day, so we have very good feedback on how they are progressing or declining, says Kao. It enables us to catch things a lot earlier than if they were only going to a clinic.

Many GeriTraCCC patients have advanced heart failure, and about one-third die within a year. Kao discusses end-of-life wishes with her patients, and supports them in achieving the highest quality of life possible. One patient was very sick, but taking care of her intensively at home enabled her to go with her spouse on a drive to Napa and to the opera things that meant a lot to the couple in the final months before she died, says Kao. Some hospitalizations are very appropriate to keep someone safe, but there are many that are preventable, and we go to great lengths to help people stay at home. Having care come to patients at home is a far more economical and patientcentered way of providing care.

For some patients with progressive late-stage heart failure, additional advanced heart failure management strategies may be employed, including heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support (heart assist devices designed to pump blood to the body in patients with a failing heart). For those in whom all management options are exhausted or for whom they are inappropriate, palliative care, provided by a compassionate team, is instituted.

Michelle Mourad, MD (right), with Ellen Knoch, RN, study telemanagement techniques to reduce heart failure readmissions.

Sharing Innovations

The heart failure readmission reduction initiative is continuing to develop better ways to prevent unnecessary readmissions. I would love to get our 30-day readmissions rate down into the single digits, says Carroll.

One component is the Better Effectiveness After Transitions Heart Failure (BEAT-HF) Trial, for which the five University of California medical centers and Cedars-Sinai Medical Center received a $9.9 million grant from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. Andrew Auerbach, MD, MPH, and Michelle Mourad, MD, lead UCSFs participation in this randomized study evaluating the effect of telemanagement techniques to reduce heart failure readmissions.

The heart failure team is also focusing on expanding collaborations with outpatient partners, training skilled nursing facilities and home care agency staff on optimal postdischarge care for heart failure patients. They are also working to apply lessons learned to reduce preventable readmissions among patients with other chronic diseases, such as pneumonia, diabetes, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. What we have learned can be disseminated across all high-risk patients, says Brinker. All patients deserve this standard of care.

Below, find recent examples of our work with patients and patient care. Some articles were published in our newsletter, the Department of Medicine's Frontiers of Medicine.

Get the Door, Its the Doctor: House Calls for Older Patients in San Francisco

Carol Jenkins Hill has been unable to walk since breaking her ankle two years ago. Her mobility was poor even before that, and despite physical therapy its almost impossible for the 73-year old to put weight on her legs. That keeps Hill, who lives in San Francisco, from doing many of the things she enjoys, like getting out to see friends. But, more significantly, it keeps her from doing the things ... Read More

Caring for the Aging Population: Innovations in Geriatrics Issue 18, Spring 2014

About 10,000 Baby Boomers turn 65 every day, and the number of seniors is expected to top 70 million by 2030. To help meet the needs of an aging population, the UCSF Division of Geriatrics is pioneering ways to provide better care to older adults, discover better therapies, and educate the next generation of medical professionals, caregivers and community members... Read More

UCSF Heart Failure Program: Improving Outcomes Issue 14, Spring 2012

Improved care of elderly patients with heart failure has led to shorter hospital stays and lower rates of death while in the hospital. Unfortunately, after leaving the hospital, many of these patients are at risk of being admitted to a nursing home, are frequently re-admitted to the hospital, or die in the month following hospital discharge ... Read More

When Less Is More: Balancing Harms, Benefits of Mammography Issue 14, Spring 2012

Early in her career, Louise Walter, MD, struggled with the decision about which of her elderly patients she should encourage to obtain a screening mammogram. When I looked at the guidelines, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommended that you stop at age 70, the American Geriatrics Society said to stop at 85, and the ... Read More

node.Fname: Care of the Aging Patient: From Evidence to Action ./geriatrics/innovations/care.html
node.FileBody:
About the Series

Care of the Aging Patient is produced by a University of California, San Francisco editorial team and appears bi-monthly in JAMA. The case-based series is designed to inform clinical practice and influence policy in care of older individuals. Excerpts from patient, family, and clinician interviews, along with the Patient's Story case history, drive the narrative of an evidence-based, peer-reviewed article that is authored by an invited expert in the field. Cases illustrate the approach and management of the entire spectrum of geriatric syndromes and disease, including the psycho-social-spiritual aspects of aging.

Care of the Aging Patient Bibliography

Lead-off Editorial

Landefeld CS, Winker MA, Chernof B. Clinical care in the aging century--announcing "Care of the aging patient: from evidence to action". JAMA. 2009 Dec 23;302(24):2703-4.

Articles

1. Reuben DB. Medical care for the final years of life: "When you're 83, it's not going to be 20 years". JAMA. 2009 Dec 23;302(24):2686-94.

2. Tinetti ME, Kumar C. The patient who falls: "It's always a trade-off". JAMA. 2010 Jan 20;303(3):258-66.

3. Carr DB, Ott BR. The older adult driver with cognitive impairment: "It's a very frustrating life". JAMA. 2010 Apr 28;303(16):1632-41.

4. Goode PS, Burgio KL, Richter HE, Markland AD. Incontinence in older women. JAMA. 2010 Jun 2;303(21):2172-81.

5. Steinman MA, Hanlon JT. Managing medications in clinically complex elders: "There's got to be a happy medium". JAMA. 2010 Oct 13;304(14):1592-601.

6. Boult C, Wieland, GD. Comprehensive primary care for older patients with multiple chronic conditions: "Nobody rushes you through". JAMA. 2010 Nov 3;304(17):1936-43.

node.Fname: Care of the Aging Patient: From Evidence to Action ./geriatrics/innovations/care_topics.html
node.FileBody:
"Care of the Aging Patient: From Evidence to Action" Future Topics

Clinical Topics

  1. Gait and mobility problems; assistive devices, how to choose them, and how patient should learn their use

  2. Delirium, application of research data

  3. Parkinson disease and special considerations and complications in older patients

  4. Kyphosis

  5. Progressive dyspnea, lung failure (restrictive lung disease due to interstitial lung disease, recurrent aspiration pneumonia) in old age

  6. Screening for breast cancer and management of early breast cancer in elderly women

  7. Screening for prostate cancer and management of early prostate cancer in elderly men

  8. Screening for colon cancer and its management in elders

  9. Screening for heart disease and its risk factors in elders

  10. Sarcopenia (undernutrition and frailty) in elders

  11. Sexual function and dysfunction: erectile dysfunction management (including when nitrates contraindicate sildenafil and related drugs), atrophic vaginitis, etc. in elders

  12. Aging and sexual orientation

  13. Orthopedic problems of elderly individuals: back pain, spinal stenosis, shoulder pain

  14. Chronic kidney disease and indications for and against dialysis in elders

  15. Stroke in elders

  16. Myocardial infarction and cardiac rehabilitation in elders

  17. Congestive heart failure, including when to use biventricular pacing in elders

  18. Sick sinus syndrome and indications for pacemaker implantation in elders

  19. Arrhythmias and indications for automatic implantable cardiac defibrillator (AICD) in elders

  20. Aortic aneurysm and newer "non-invasive" approaches in elders

  21. Alcoholism (and substance use) in older patients

  22. Physical therapy for musculoskeletal conditions; how to write a prescription for PT for older adults

  23. Perioperative management in elders

  24. Sleep disorders in older adults/Insomnia

  25. Pain management

  26. Visual disorders of aging: e.g., senile macular degeneration ("wet" and "dry"), cataract, etc.

  27. Ear, nose and throat (ENT) disorders: hoarseness and dysphonia, presbycusis, tinnitus, vertigo, etc. in older adults

  28. Common skin problems: onychomycosis, actinic keratosis, skin cancers, pressure ulcers, etc. in older adults

  29. Diabetes mellitus, type 2 in older adults

  30. Thyroid disorders such as hypothyroidism due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis, "subclinical" hypothyroidism and "subclinical" hyperthyroidism in older adults

  31. Hyperparathyroidism in the elderly (including when to operate)

  32. Treatment of hypertension, including management of resulting problems, such as orthostatic hypotension

  33. Primary and secondary prevention of stroke and coronary artery disease (CAD) in elders

  34. Common rheumatologic disorders (calcium pyrophosphate deposition (CPPD) disease, polymyalgia rheumatica, rheumatoid arthritis) in elders

  35. Constipation, its complications (rectal prolapse, fecal incontinence), and its management

  36. Anticoagulation in elders (warfarin and falls, subcutaneous heparin and long-term care)

  37. Nosocomial infection (eg, Clostridium difficile) in older adults

Institutional/Site of Care Topics

  1. Tension between justice and autonomy in nursing homes

  2. Sexual behaviors in nursing homes

  3. Intensive care unit care in elders

  4. Readmission/unnecessary admissions

Other Topics

  1. Technology in care of the aged, including Telecare and remote monitoring

  2. Efficacy of the geriatrics approach and its application to patients outside of clinical trials

  3. The increasing disconnection between geriatric research and practice

  4. Geriatric assessment in primary care

  5. Aging in various ethnic traditions: what the physician needs to know

A prognostic index is a clinical tool to aid in predicting the prognosis of a patient. Although many geriatric prognostic indices have been published, they may be difficult for busy clinicians to remember and use. The goal of ePrognosis is to be a repository of published geriatric prognostic indices where clinicians can go to obtain evidence-based information on patients prognosis.

10/2014: Dr. Alex Smith was one of six people chosen to give a TED-like talk at the Department of Medicine Strategic Planning retreat on October 11, 2014. The talks are meant to highlight some of the innovative and inspiring work that is happening in the UCSF Department of Medicine. Six people were chosen to give talks out of 36 nominations. Dr. Smiths talk is focused on prognosis the expected outcomes of treatment.

For more information please visit ePrognosis.

The GeriPal (Geriatrics and Palliative Care) Weblog is a forum for discourse, recent news and research, and freethinking commentary.

GeriPals objectives are to create an online community of interdisciplinary providers interested in geriatrics or palliative care and to provide an open forum for the exchange of ideas and disruptive commentary that changes clinical practice and health care policy. The site welcomes the perspectives and comments of generalists, specialists, gerontologists, palliative care clinicians, and anyone else interested in care of the elderly or palliative care. GeriPal has been mentioned/cited in the national press, including the NY Times and MSNBC, as well academic journals such as Palliative Medicine and the Lancet.

For more information please visit GeriPal.

The Division of Geriatrics fosters healthcare transformation by finding new ways to improve the health and care of older persons. The projects listed below are examples of what the Division is currently working on:

The Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF is empowering San Francisco to meet the needs facing older adults. Based in the Division of Geriatrics, we train health and social service providers in how to serve older adults with excellence and come together to better coordinate efforts across sectors. We also work with primary care health systems to improve their care for older adults. Our training and health care innovations especially focus on those vulnerable individuals who have dementia, live alone, or are LGBTQ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer or questioning).

Now is the time our collaborative is needed. In San Francisco more than 170,000 residents are age 60 or older, accounting for almost 22 percent of the citys population, which is much higher than the national average of 18%. Additionally older adults often need to manage multiple health conditions and face many unmet social needs, such as inadequate income for medicine, housing and food. The caregivers that love and care for them also need support and resources to do what is often a complicated and demanding job.

The Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF was founded in July 2015 as a Geriatric Workforce Enhancement Program by the U.S. Health Resources and Services Administration. Our collaborative includes experts in public, nonprofit, and academic organizations to provide education and innovative services that address older adults health, social, and legal needs. The UCSF Division of Geriatrics is recognized throughout the medical community as a world leader in the areas of research, education and clinical care for older adults.

Through our attention to vulnerable older adults, our dynamic citywide partnerships, and our expertise, the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF is developing innovative solutions to improving the quality of care and health outcomes for older adults in San Francisco. We provide models for care and collaboration that other cities can replicate and seek to improve care for all. We are also working on developing resources for education and care.

Funding and Donations

The Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF is one of 44 Geriatrics Workforce Enhancement Programs (GWEPs) in 29 states to receive funding from the U.S. Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA). This funding is set to expire in June of 2018.

Are you interested in supporting our work? Help us achieve a fully geriatrics-competent community by making a secure online donation via Geriatrics Make a Gift. Please click Choose a designation and enter GWEP.

You may also send a check that indicates GWEP as your designation preference to:

UCSF
PO Box 45339
San Francisco, CA 94145-0339
Payable to: UCSF Foundation

All gifts are tax deductible in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code.

The PREPARE website is designed to help people and their loved ones prepare for medical decision making.

 

For more information, please visit the PREPARE website and Facebook page.

The UCSF Program for the Aging Century was founded in 2011 to catalyze the transformation of health care for the oldest Americans. These models will, in turn, inform national policy so successes will be translated into practice across the nation.

The Program for the Aging Century was established at UCSF in 2011 through the support of the S.D. Bechtel, Jr. Foundation. Closely associated with the UCSF Division of Geriatrics, the Program was created in response to the biggest demographic shift of this century the aging of the worldwide population. The Program is committed to attracting and sustaining people of exceptional talent as they build transformational models in education, health care, and discovery. The Program for the Aging Century seeks to bring together leaders who will make breakthroughs and create change on a national level through ideas to transform medicine and health care for the Aging Century, and to build communication between these leaders in aging-related services and the greater community. For more information please visit The Program for the Aging Century website.

Tideswell at UCSF focuses on one of the greatest needs in healthcare today improving the quality of care for older adults with chronic conditions and functional limitations living in our communities. This population accounts for a large portion of healthcare costs in the U.S. By applying and adapting the most compelling research, care models, and training to the real needs of older adults in our communities, our work greatly improves the quality of care while significantly relieving the burden on families, communities, and the economy.

Historically, scientific research has not focused on the needs and concerns of older adults or their caregivers. Older adults are routinely excluded from large research trials of medicines and clinical innovations, and, as a consequence, evidenced based approaches to care for older patients are not often put into practice.

What We Do

We are committed to improving care for aging adults living in our communities by:

  • Developing, testing and disseminating best practices for providing optimal patient care
  • Attracting and training caregivers and future leaders in the field
  • Partnering with others focused on elder care

Why We Do It

Current standards and accessibility of caring for the aging must be transformed so that:

  • Every person has the knowledge and skills to treat older adults with the dignity they deserve
  • Older adults receive the optimal care that they need now and can continue to live fulfilling lives in the community

For more information please visit the Tideswell website.
Content goes here.

The Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF is a partnership of San Franciscos leading public, human service, and academic organizations. Each organization of this unique partnership brings important expertise and necessary resources to achieve our goal of enhancing and unifying care of older adults. Our human service non-profit partners are organizations with expertise in caring for older adults who have dementia, are living alone, or are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer or questioning (LGBTQ). Our public partners are large inter-professional organizations with diverse, low-income, underserved clientele, and our academic partners are institutions of education for medicine, social work, and law.

node.Fname: Healthcare Providers OAC Toolkit Items: Clinical Assessment of Older Adults ./geriatrics/innovations/oac/healthcareproviders.html
node.FileBody:
Resources specifically culminated for physicians, trainees, nurses, social workers, and other healthcare professionals

Cognition

  • Mini-Cog Screening Tool: Simple and fast screening tool used to detect cognitive impairment during both routine visits and hospitalizations. Administration takes approximately three minutes. If score is poor, MoCA Tool suggested as follow-up. (#cognition)
    How Its Used: The Mini-Cog Screening Tool is used by our UCSF providers and health care professional partners throughout San Francisco. We have incorporated a series of trainings for professionals at the San Francisco Department of Aging and Adult Services (DAAS) on how to assess clients, manage care, and refer to additional services.

  • Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) Tool: Screening tool for mild cognitive impairment and dementia. Assesses various cognitive domains such as attention and concentration and conceptual thinking. Administration takes approximately 10 minutes. (#cognition) See test here.
    How Its Used: The MoCA Tool has been incorporated into our regular trainings of physicians, health professional trainees, behavioral health clinicians, and social services professionals. Social services professionals, in particular, receive education on how to assess clients with mild cognitive function and information on available services for referral.

  • National Institute on Aging Talking with Your Older Patient: A Clinicians Handbook: A guide available to clinicians to assess cognitive problems, discuss supportive services, and assist the patient and caregiver. (#cognition)
    How Its Used: This clinician handbook is used to provide health professionals guidance on how to address cognition in older adults, refer patients to health and social services, and support patients and family members. This handbook is one of several resources highlighted in the curriculum of our Cognition Key.

Independence

  • Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB): A performance-based, three-part assessment to measure functional status and predict future functional decline. Assessment includes gait speed, balance, and lower extremity strength. Takes approximately 10 minutes to administer.
    How Its Used: The SPPB is a cornerstone to our Medicare AWV+, an enhanced health promotion-focused visit for Medicare beneficiaries. Facilitated by our physician residents and graduate nursing students, the SPPB score provides specific information regarding functional performance
    SPPB Instructions

  • Whisper Test: Simple and accurate screening test to detect hearing impairment. Administration takes one to two minutes.
    How Its Used: The Whisper Test is also utilized in our Medicare AWV+ Visits as a way to identify potential hearing loss or issues and refer patients to audiology services to ensure independence and optimal aging.
    Whisper Test Instructions

Safety

  • Detecting Elder Abuse and Neglect: Assessment and Intervention Article in Journal of American Family Physician
    How Its Used: This resource reviews a variety of tools are available for detecting, assessing, and intervening in cases of older adult abuse and neglect. There is not one tool that we universally recommend for detecting and addressing elder abuse. This resource is highlighted in our Safety Key.

  • U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Stopping Elderly Accidents, Deaths, and Injuries (STEADI)
    How Its Used: The CDC STEADI resources and booklets are provided to patients, along with consultation on older adult safety, at the conclusion of each Medicare AWV+ visit. Patients have reported learning actionable steps to improve their safety, independence, and wellbeing as a result of these visits and resources.

Individualized Goal Setting and Decision-Making

  • Physicians Guide to Talking About End-of-Life Care Article in Journal of General Internal Medicine
    How Its Used: This guide is recommended for physicians, healthcare providers, and trainees on how to engage patients in often-difficult conversations around end-of-life care and advance care planning. It is reviewed and taught in our Individualized Goal Setting and Decision-Making Key.

  • Advance Care Planning as an Element of the Annual Wellness Visit
    How Its Used: We have incorporated comprehensive advance care planning into our Medicare AWV+ Visits. With this resource, our UCSF clinicians and trainees have access to official information from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.

  • Go Wish Card Game: An easy, even entertaining way to think about lifes priorities, Go Wish Cards help patients, families, and friends talk about advance care planning and end-of-life wishes.
    • How Its Used: A set of Go Wish Cards is provided to all patients upon the completion of an AWV+ Visit. Our physician residents and graduate nursing students use the cards as an opportunity to discuss with older adult patients their health wishes and the importance of advance care planning.

Mental Health

  • Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9): Common short screening tool used to identify depression.
    How Its Used: Our UCSF health providers and San Francisco Department of Aging and Adult Services (DAAS) social service professionals regularly utilize the PHQ-9 tool, which has been validated in older adults. We have provided a series of trainings and education sessions on the implementation and use of this questionnaire to screen and identify patients with depression. It is reviewed an taught in our Mental Health Key.

  • Geriatric Depression Scale (Short Form): A 15-item, short screening tool utilized to detect depression in older adults. It has been validated in older populations. Administration of questionnaire takes approximately three minutes. It is reviewed and taught in our Mental Health Key.
    How Its Used: In the AWV+ Visits, if the Patient Health Questionnaire is positive, the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) is performed. The GDS is a reliable and validated depression screening tool used by our UCSF health providers and San Francisco Department of Aging and Adult Services (DAAS) professionals with older adults who may be at risk of depressed mood.

  • Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-7): Seven-question screening tool to identify anxiety disorders.
    How Its Used: The GAD-7 screening tool is used by our clinicians in AWV+ Visits to identify anxiety disorders among older adult patients. UCSF clinicians and trainees also regularly use this tool with patients in visits and screenings. It is reviewed and taught in our Mental Health Key.

  • SAMSHA-HRSA Screening, Brief Intervention and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) Tools: Evidence-based resources used for identification, reduction, and prevention of problematic use, abuse, and dependence on alcohol and illicit drugs.
    How Its Used: Our UCSF clinicians and trainees use this tool to identify, assess, and refer older adult patients with alcohol and drug use disorders. This resource provides guidance to our health professionals in engaging older adults to address disorders and refer patients to effective drug and alcohol services. It is reviewed and taught in our Mental Health Key.

Additional Resources

  • Oklahoma Healthy Aging Initiative AgeASiST Kits: Simulation kits used to provide aging-sensitivity training, including sensations of vision loss, hearing loss, neuropathy, aphasia, and mobility/balance issues.
    How Its Used: We have incorporated the AgeASiST Kits into our regular trainings for local law enforcement including the San Francisco Police Department (SFPD) and San Francisco Recreation and Parks Department (SFRPD). Trainees have the ability to experience symptoms of aging such as hearing and sight loss and mobility limitations.
  • LGBT Best Practices and Assumptions
  • LGBT Training Tips
  • Living Alone Best Practices

Training

The Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF addresses gaps in the care of older adults through innovative training and health systems improvement. The Five Keys to Older Adult Health and Well-Being are the foundational topic areas for our curriculum and the unifying citywide strategy for improving care and services for older adults.

Five Keys Curriculum

We have a novel curriculum organized around the Five Keys, and we train a wide range of medical and community service providers, as well as older adults and families. Developed by our entire collaborative, our trainings and educational resources are focused on the following Five Keys topic areas:

  1. CognitionRecognizing Alzheimers disease and other dementias
  2. IndependenceImproving function, vision, and hearing
  3. SafetyPreventing falls, elder abuse, and medication side effects
  4. Individualized Goal SettingDiscussing older adults priorities and encouraging self-management and prevention
  5. Mental HealthAddressing common mental health disorders, suicide, and caregiver health

Additionally, to focus on vulnerable populations, the curriculum includes input from specific experts among our group. Openhouse provides information about issues facing LGBTQ populations. Alzheimers Association - Northern California and Northern Nevada Chapter serves as an expert on Alzheimers disease and related dementias. And, UC Hastings School of Law provides invaluable guidance on comprehensive advanced care planning. All these experts also advise on the care of older adults who live alone.

Experts on caregiver services from both Homebridge and Little Brothers Friends of the Elderly contribute to clinical materials for lay caregivers and health care providers to help close gaps in understanding about what caregivers do. All these experts also advise on the care of older adults who live alone.

Five Keys Strategy

The Five Keys are the basis of our work with primary care health systems, including the San Francisco Health Network, the SF Veterans Affairs Medical Centers, and the Division of General Internal Medicine at UCSF Mt. Zion, and social service agencies (see Our Community Partners). Through site-specific initiatives, we are supporting work to improve and evaluate the way older adults receive critical geriatrics health care and social services in the Five Keys areas. By collaborating across many sectors, we seek to close gaps in the safety net for older adults in San Francisco.

Our Reach

The Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF delivers trainings, educational resources, and professional development to a diverse collection of individuals and organizations focused on providing care for older adults including:

  • Older Adults, Families, and Caregivers
  • Medical Doctors
  • Nursing Professionals
  • First Responders and Law Enforcement Professionals
  • Behavioral Health and Social Work Professionals

Below are a few testimonials from our trainings:

It was valuable to get an overview of what dementia actually is and how to distinguish the different forms, and most importantly what to look for in terms of 'warning signs'. I don't work in elder care professionally, but I volunteer regularly with an 83-year-old elder. I had been wondering how to notice the progression from 'normal' age-related, occasional forgetfulness to something more serious, and this session gave some really good pointers to look out for. Luckily, it seems my elder is not nearing actual dementia yet! - Community Caregiver

The information and discussion on geriatric prognostication was very valuable. UCSF Third Year Resident in Internal Medicine.

Quality Improvement

As an organization committed to quality improvement in health and human services, the Optimizing Aging Collaborative at UCSF has adopted several innovative practices in our program operations and evaluation. These include:

  • Using a novel tiered-training approach to geriatrics-primary care integration that maximizes geriatrics impact and strengthens our health care workforce.
  • Managing all project operations in accordance with LEAN principles to maximize the value of structures and processes for our trainees and our funder, the U.S. Health Resources and Services Administration.
  • Gathering theoretically supported evaluation data on structure, process and outcomes to provide transparent reporting and continuous quality improvement in our curriculum development, as well as our training implementation.
